{{short description|American actress}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox person | image = MarleeMatlinMay09crop.JPG | caption = Matlin receiving a [[List of stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame#M|Motion Pictures Star]] at the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] in 2009 | birth_name = Marlee Beth Matlin | birth_date = {{birth date and age |1965|8|24}} | birth_place = [[Morton Grove, Illinois]], U.S. | other_names = | occupation = Actress, author | years_active = 1986–present | known_for =''[[Children of a Lesser God (film)|Children of a Lesser God]]'', ''[[Switched at Birth (TV series)|Switched at Birth]]'', ''[[The West Wing]]'', ''[[The L Word]]'' | children = 4 | website = {{URL|marleematlinsite.com/}} | spouse = {{marriage|Kevin Grandalski
|1993|}} | partner = [[William Hurt]]
(1985–1986) }} '''Marlee Beth Matlin''' (born August 24, 1965) is an American actress, author, and activist. She won the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]] for ''[[Children of a Lesser God (film)|Children of a Lesser God]]'' (1986) and to date is the only [[Deafness|deaf]] performer to have won an Academy Award.{{Cite news|url=https://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1987/memorable-moments|title=The 59th Academy Awards Memorable Moments|date=August 26, 2014|work=Oscars.org {{!}} Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|access-date=7 March 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/article/2012/02/21/oscars-marlee-matlin/|title=Oscars: Marlee Matlin on her Best Actress win|date=February 21, 2012|work=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=7 March 2017}} Her work in film and television has resulted in a [[Golden Globe]] award, with two additional nominations, and four [[Emmy]] nominations. Deaf since she was 18 months old, due to illness and high fevers,{{cite book|last1=Matlin|first1=Marlee|title=I'll Scream Later|date=2009|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781439117637|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_soaGRKGBwAC&q|language=en|page=3}} she is also a prominent member of the [[National Association of the Deaf (United States)|National Association of the Deaf]]. Her longtime interpreter is Jack Jason.[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129130484 "Marlee Matlin: ‘Do What You Have To Do’"], NPR, August 11, 2010.Rick Rojas, [http://articles.latimes.com/2011/may/21/entertainment/la-et-matlin-interpreter-20110521 "Jack Jason gives voice to, but doesn't talk over, Marlee Matlin"], ''Los Angeles Times'', May 21, 2011. ==Early life== Matlin was born in [[Morton Grove, Illinois]], to Libby (née Hammer) and Donald Matlin (1930–2013), who was an automobile dealer.[http://www.filmreference.com/film/9/Marlee-Matlin.html Marlee Matlin profile], FilmReference.com. Retrieved February 7, 2018.{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/celeb/matlin.htm|title=Marlee Beth Matlin roots|publisher=Rootsweb.com|accessdate=June 16, 2012}}{{cite web|date=April 14, 2009|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/DancingStars/story?id=7324917&page=4|title=Inside Actress Marlee Matlin's Silent World|work=Good Morning America|publisher=ABC|at=p. 4|accessdate=June 16, 2012}} She lost all hearing in her right ear and 80% of the hearing in her left ear at the age of 18 months. In her autobiography ''I'll Scream Later'', she suggests that her hearing loss may have been due to a genetically malformed [[cochlea]].{{cite book|last1=Matlin|first1=Marlee|title=I'll Scream Later|date=2009|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781439117637|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_soaGRKGBwAC&pg=PT14&dq=%22It+all+began+for+me+on+August+24,+1965%22#v=onepage&q=genetically%20malformed&f=false|language=en|pages=21–22}} She is the only member of her family who is deaf. She and her two older brothers, Eric and Marc, grew up in a [[Reform Jewish]] household. Her family roots are in Poland and Russia.Schleier, Curt, [http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/31384/edition_id/587/format/html/displaystory.html "No challenge goes unmet for Deaf actress Marlee Matlin"], ''Jewish News Weekly'', January 19, 2007.{{cite book|last1=Matlin|first1=Marlee|title=I'll Scream Later|date=2009|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781439117637|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_soaGRKGBwAC&pg=PT14&dq=%22It+all+began+for+me+on+August+24,+1965%22|language=en}} Matlin attended a synagogue for the Deaf (Congregation Bene Shalom), and after studying [[Liturgical Hebrew|Hebrew]] phonetically, was able to learn her Torah portion for her Bat Mitzvah. She was later interviewed for the book ''Mazel Tov: Celebrities' Bar and Bat Mitzvah Memories''.[https://www.amazon.com/dp/0743287878 "Mazel Tov: Celebrities' Bar and Bat Mitzvah Memories"], Amazon.com. Retrieved February 7, 2018. Matlin graduated from [[John Hersey High School]] in [[Arlington Heights, Illinois|Arlington Heights]] and attended [[Harper College]].Heidemann, Jason A. [http://www.timeout.com/chicago/article/over-out/23057/vital-signs "Vital signs"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013044809/http://www.timeout.com/chicago/article/over-out/23057/vital-signs|date=October 13, 2007}}. ''Time Out Chicago'', October 4, 2007. In her autobiography ''I'll Scream Later'', she described two instances when she was molested: by her babysitter at age 11, and by her teacher in high school.{{cite book|last=Matlin|first=Marlee|title=I'll Scream Later|date=2010|location=London, UK|isbn=978-1439171516|edition=First|pages= 56–61 }} ==Career== Matlin made her stage debut at the age of seven, as Dorothy in an [[International Center on Deafness and the Arts]] ([[ICODA]]) children's theatre of ''[[The Wonderful Wizard of Oz|The Wizard of Oz]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.4hearingloss.com/archives/2006/08/a_gateway_to_ar.html|title=A gateway to arts for the deaf|publisher=4hearingloss.com|date=August 18, 2006|accessdate=November 9, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060902085100/http://www.4hearingloss.com/archives/2006/08/a_gateway_to_ar.html|archivedate = September 2, 2006}} and continued to appear with the ICODA children's theatre group throughout her childhood.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20094814,00.html|title=Deaf Actress Marlee Matlin Broke the Sound Barrier with New Love and Lesser God Co-Star Bill Hurt|last=Stark|first=John|date=October 20, 1986|work=People|accessdate=December 18, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006140152/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20094814,00.html|archivedate=October 6, 2014}} Her discovery by [[Henry Winkler]] during one of her ICODA theater performances ultimately led to her film debut in ''[[Children of a Lesser God (film)|Children of a Lesser God]]'' (1986).{{cite web|url=http://www.greatertalent.com/matlinwinkler/|title=Why Marlee Matlin and Henry Winkler are captivating audiences|publisher=Greater Talent|accessdate=12 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222125057/http://www.greatertalent.com/matlinwinkler/|archivedate=December 22, 2015}} That film brought her a [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Drama]] and an [[Academy Award for Best Actress]]. Two years later, she made a guest appearance on ''[[Sesame Street]]'' with [[Billy Joel]] performing a revised version of "[[Just the Way You Are (Billy Joel song)|Just the Way You Are]]" with lyrics by [[Tony Geiss]].{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} Matlin used sign language during the song and hugged [[Oscar the Grouch]] during the song's conclusion. One year after that, Billy Joel invited her to perform in his video for "[[We Didn't Start the Fire]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.billyjoel.com/news/girl-video-we-didnt-start-fire-marc-tyler-nobleman/|title=The Girl in the Video: ‘We Didn’t Start The Fire’|website=''Billyjoel.com''|author=Tyler, Marc}} In 1989, Matlin portrayed a deaf widow in ''Bridge to Silence''. In that role, she spoke in addition to using sign language. She was nominated for a Golden Globe for her work as the lead female role in the television series ''[[Reasonable Doubts]]'' (1991–1993). Matlin was nominated for an [[Emmy Award]] for a guest appearance in ''[[Picket Fences]]'' (1992) and became a regular on that series during its final season (1996). She played [[Carrie Buck]] in the 1994 television drama ''Against Her Will: The Carrie Buck Story'', based on the 1927 [[United States Supreme Court]] case ''[[Buck v. Bell]]'' 274 U.S. 200. In that role, Matlin portrayed a hearing woman for the first time in her career, which earned her a CableACE Nomination as Best Actress.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} Matlin later had recurring roles in ''[[The West Wing]]'', and ''[[Blue's Clues]]''. Other television appearances include ''[[Seinfeld]]'' ("[[The Lip Reader]]"), ''[[The Outer Limits (1995 TV series)|The Outer Limits]]'' ("[[The Message (The Outer Limits)|The Message]]"), ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', ''[[The Practice]],'' and ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]''. She was nominated for [[Emmy Awards|Primetime Emmy Awards]] for her guest appearances in ''Seinfeld'', ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'', and ''The Practice''.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} [[File:Marlee matlan 2007.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Matlin at the 2007 [[Texas Book Festival]] promoting one of her works]] In 2002, Matlin published her first novel, titled ''Deaf Child Crossing,'' which was loosely based on her own childhood. She later wrote and published a sequel titled ''Nobody's Perfect'', produced on stage at the John F. Kennedy Center for Performing Arts in partnership with VSA Arts in October 2007. In 2004, she starred in the movie ''[[What the Bleep Do We Know!?]]'' as Amanda. Also in 2003, she hosted the 3rd Annual [[Festival for Cinema of the Deaf]] in Chicago.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} In 2006, she played a deaf parent in ''[[Desperate Housewives]]''. She had a recurring role as [[Joy Turner]]'s (who made many jokes about Matlin's deafness at her expense) public defender in ''[[My Name Is Earl]]'' and played the mother of one of the victims in an episode of ''[[CSI: NY]].'' That same year, Matlin was cast in season 4 of ''[[The L Word]]'' as [[Jodi Lerner]], a [[lesbian]] sculptor. She appeared in season 4 (2007), season 5 (2008), and season 6 (2009) as the girlfriend of one of the show's protagonists, [[Bette Porter]], played by [[Jennifer Beals]].{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} On February 4, 2007, and February 7, 2016, Matlin interpreted the "[[Star Spangled Banner]]" in [[American Sign Language]] at [[Super Bowl XLI]] in Miami, Florida and at [[Super Bowl 50]] in [[Santa Clara, California]], respectively. In January 2008, she appeared on ''[[Nip/Tuck]]'' as a television executive.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} In 2008, Matlin participated as a competitor in the sixth season of [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]].'' Her dance partner was newcomer [[Fabian Sanchez]]. Matlin and Sanchez were the sixth couple eliminated from the competition.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20423845,00.html|title=Marlee Matlin Signs Off from Dancing|work=People|date=April 23, 2008|accessdate=December 18, 2011}} On May 6, 2009, Matlin received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.[http://www.laindependent.com/news/44496947.html "Marlee Matlin receives Walk of Fame star"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930060422/http://www.laindependent.com/news/44496947.html|date=September 30, 2011}}, ''The Los Angeles Independent'', May 6, 2009. On November 8, 2009, Matlin appeared on ''Seth & Alex's Almost Live Comedy Show'', hosted by [[Seth MacFarlane]] and [[Alex Borstein]]. After Borstein imitated Matlin calling MovieFone and singing "[[Poker Face (Lady Gaga song)|Poker Face]]," Matlin herself appeared and launched into a comical tirade against Borstein over being made fun of, and how she was not invited to provide her own voice for ''[[Family Guy]].'' Matlin went on to voice Stella, [[Peter Griffin]]'s coworker, in the Season 10 episode "[[The Blind Side (Family Guy)|The Blind Side]];" Stella later became a recurring character. In 2010, Matlin produced a pilot for a reality show she titled ''My Deaf Family,'' which she presented to various national network executives. Although they expressed interest, no network purchased rights to the show. On March 29, 2010, Matlin uploaded the pilot to YouTube and launched a viral marketing campaign.{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.aol.com/2010/03/31/marlee-matlin-launches-my-deaf-family-on-youtube|title=Marlee Matlin Launches ''My Deaf Family'' on YouTube|publisher=Insidetv.aol.com|date=March 31, 2010|accessdate=October 29, 2011}} On July 26, 2010, Matlin signed a speech at an event commemorating the 20th anniversary of the [[Americans with Disabilities Act]].[http://www.whitehouse.gov/photos-and-video/video/20th-anniversary-americans-with-disabilities-act 20th Anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act], The White House.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702174208/http://www.whitehouse.gov/photos-and-video/video/20th-anniversary-americans-with-disabilities-act|date=July 2, 2012}} In the following year, Matlin was a finalist on the NBC show ''[[The Celebrity Apprentice]],'' competing to win money for her charity, The Starkey Hearing Foundation,{{cite web|url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/218323/celebrity-apprentice-marlee-matlins-charity|title=The Celebrity Apprentice|publisher=[[Hulu]]}} finishing in second place. However, on one episode of ''The Celebrity Apprentice'', "The Art of the Deal", which was transmitted on April 3, 2011, she raised more funds than had ever been raised for charity in a single event on any television show before, $986,000.[http://www.disabled-world.com/disability/types/hearing/marlee-matlin.php "SignTalk Joins Fundraiser for Marlee Matlin's Cause..."], disabled-world.com, May 12, 2011. [[Donald Trump]], who was then hosting ''The Celebrity Apprentice,'' then donated an additional $14,000 to make the contribution an even million. In 2013, Matlin played herself in ''[[No Ordinary Hero: The SuperDeafy Movie]]''. As of January 2015, Matlin also acted as the [[American Civil Liberties Union|ACLU]]'s celebrity ambassador for disability rights.{{cite web |url=https://www.aclu.org/ambassadors|title= ACLU Ambassadors – Marlee Matlin|publisher=aclu.olrg (American Civil Liberties Union)|accessdate=5 January 2015}} As a "celebrity ambassador" for the ACLU, in attempts to bridge the gap between law enforcement and the deaf community, Matlin discussed the communication barriers when deaf individuals are stopped by the police.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/video/marlee-matlin-deaf-and-police-interaction|title=Marlee Matlin on Deaf And Police Interaction|date=March 22, 2018|website=ACLU}} Matlin played the recurring character of Melody Bledsoe on ''[[Switched at Birth (TV series)|Switched at Birth]]''. In September 2015, she made her Broadway debut in the revival production of the musical ''[[Spring Awakening (Musical)|Spring Awakening]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/children-of-a-lesser-god-oscar-winner-marlee-matlin-will-make-broadway-debut-in-spring-awakening-353669|title=''Children of a Lesser God'' Oscar Winner Marlee Matlin Will Make Broadway Debut in ''Spring Awakening''|date=July 21, 2015|accessdate=November 8, 2015|website=Playbill|last=Gioia|first= Michael|last2=Viagas|first2=Robert}} Beginning in 2017, Matlin played the recurring role of Harriet on the Syfy television series, ''[[The Magicians (U.S. TV series)|The Magicians]]''.{{cite magazine|last=Serrao|first=Nivea|date=February 9, 2017|title=Marlee Matlin to cast her spell on ''The Magicians''|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/02/09/the-magicians-marlee-matlin|access-date=January 12, 2018}} On July 31, 2017, it was announced by Deadline that Matlin joined as a series regular in the third season of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] thriller ''[[Quantico (TV series)|Quantico]]''. She starred in the role of ex-[[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agent Jocelyn Turner.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/07/quantico-marlee-matlin-cast-season-3-abc-series-1202139672|title=‘Quantico’: Marlee Matlin Cast in Season 3 of ABC Series|last=Petski|first=Denise|date=July 31, 2017|publisher=Deadline Hollywood|access-date=August 7, 2017}} ==Personal life== Matlin is actively involved with a number of charitable organizations, including [[Easterseals (U.S.)|Easter Seals]] (where she was appointed an Honorary board member), the Children Affected by AIDS Foundation, [[Elizabeth Glaser Pediatric AIDS Foundation]], [[VSA arts]], and the [[Red Cross]] Celebrity Cabinet.{{cite web |url=http://www.voicesinc.com/Pages/marlee_matlin.html |title=Marlee Matlin, The Gift of Silence: A Conversation with Marlee Matlin |publisher=Voices Inc.com |date=April 4, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070602131247/http://voicesinc.com/Pages/marlee_matlin.html |archivedate=June 2, 2007}} She was appointed by [[Bill Clinton|President Clinton]] in 1994 to the Corporation for National Service and served as chair of National Volunteer Week.{{cite web|url=http://www.kennedy-center.org/artist/A60279|title=Marlee Matlin Biography|publisher=The Kennedy Center|accessdate=12 December 2015}} Matlin was a participant in the first-ever national television advertising campaign supporting donations to Jewish federations. The program featured "film and television personalities celebrating their Jewish heritage and promoting charitable giving to the Jewish community" and included [[Greg Grunberg]], [[Joshua Malina]], [[Kevin Weisman]], and [[Jonathan Silverman]].[http://www.jewishfederations.org/page.aspx?id=69595 "Film and Television Celebrities Promote Jewish Federations in First-Ever National Television Advertising Campaign – Jewish Stars Promote Federations' Initiatives and Mission"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103142605/http://www.jewishfederations.org/page.aspx?id=69595 |date=November 3, 2013 }}, Jewish Federations of North America, August 2, 2004. [[File:Matlin at 2014 AHA Hero Dog Awards.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Matlin as one of the presenters at the 2014 [[AHA Hero Dog Awards]]]] Matlin received an honorary [[Doctorate of Humane Letters]] degree from [[Gallaudet University]] in 1987.{{cite web|url=http://saveourdeafschools.org/marlee_matlin_honorary_degree_transcript_1987.pdf |title=Transcript of honorary degree ceremony at Gallaudet |format=PDF |accessdate=October 29, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://gallyprotest.org/tower_clock_1987_page_368.pdf |title=Photo in 1987 Gallaudet Tower Clock yearbook |format=PDF |accessdate=October 29, 2011}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20080314031620/http://www.gallaudet.edu/x4988.xml ''Profile: Marlee Matlin'']. Gallaudet University. Access date: December 26, 2007. In October 2007, she was appointed to the Gallaudet University Board of Trustees. In 1988, Matlin received the Samuel S. Beard Award for Greatest Public Service by an Individual 35 Years or Under, an award given out annually by Jefferson Awards.{{Cite web|url = http://www.jeffersonawards.org/pastwinners/national|title = Past Winners – Greatest Public Service by an Individual 35 Years or Under|accessdate = November 9, 2015|website = ''jeffersonawards.org''|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101124043935/http://jeffersonawards.org/pastwinners/national|archivedate = November 24, 2010}}{{Cite news|url = http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1988/Koop-Marlee-Matlin-Win-Awards-for-Public-Service/id-e6f541e226f925b86124f0b16e970cd1|title = Koop, Marlee Matlin Win Awards for Public Service|last = Rubin|first = James H.|date = June 21, 1988|agency = Associated Press|access-date = November 9, 2015}} Matlin attended the 1987 Oscars to present the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]].{{cite book|isbn=1-4391-7151-3|title=I'll Scream Later |author=Marlee Matlin, Betsy Sharkey |publisher=Simon and Schuster|year=2009}} After signing her introduction in [[ASL]], she spoke aloud the "names of the nominees" and of [[Michael Douglas]], the winner. On April 14, 2009, Matlin released an autobiography, ''I'll Scream Later''. In it, she describes her drug abuse and how it drove her to check herself into the [[Betty Ford Center]]. She also tells about her rocky, two-year relationship with her significantly older ''Children of a Lesser God'' co-star [[William Hurt]], who she claims was physically abusive to her.{{cite web|author=William Hurt |url=http://www.eonline.com/uberblog/b118626_william_hurt_marlee_matlin_i_apologize.html |title=William Hurt to Marlee Matlin: "I Apologize for Any Pain I Caused" |publisher=E! |date=April 14, 2009 |accessdate=October 29, 2011}} She also addresses the sexual abuse she suffered as a child at the hands of her female babysitter.[http://www.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Movies/04/14/lkl.marlee.matlin/index.html "Marlee Matlin: Baby sitter's abuse led to life of drugs, violence"]. CNN. April 14, 2009. She enjoys a sense of humor about her deafness: "Often I’m talking to people through my speaker phone, and after 10 minutes or so they say, 'Wait a minute, Marlee, how can you hear me?' They forget I have an interpreter there who is signing to me as they talk. So I say, 'You know what? I can hear on Wednesdays.'"{{cite web|url = http://abilitymagazine.com/past/Marleem/Marleem.html|title = ''Ability Magazine: Marlee Matlin Story''|accessdate = November 9, 2015|last = Sterman|first = Paul}}{{cite news|last1=Helling|first1=Steve|title=Marlee Matlin Addresses Reports that Donald Trump Called Her 'Retarded': 'The Term is Abhorrent'|url=http://people.com/politics/marlee-matlin-speaks-out-about-reports-that-donald-trump-called-her-retarded/|work=People|date=October 14, 2016}} ===Marriage=== Matlin married Burbank police officer Kevin Grandalski on August 29, 1993, at the home of actor [[Henry Winkler]], five days after her 28th birthday.{{cite journal|date=July 25, 1994|title=Weddings of the Year|journal=People|volume=42|issue=4|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20103514,00.html}} They first met while she was filming a scene from ''Reasonable Doubts'' outside the studio grounds; the police department had assigned Grandalski to provide security and control traffic.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20109966,00.html|title=Law and Ardor|last=Lipton|first=Michael A.|date=March 15, 1993|work=People|accessdate=December 18, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927190922/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20109966,00.html|archivedate=September 27, 2013}} They have four children: Sarah (born 1996), Brandon (born 2000), Tyler (born 2002), and Isabelle (born 2003).{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20196156,00.html|title=At Home with Marlee Matlin|last=Rizzo|first=Monica|date=March 28, 2008|work=People|accessdate=December 18, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927190759/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20196156,00.html|archivedate=September 27, 2013}} ==Filmography== {{Main|Marlee Matlin filmography}} == Awards == {{Main|List of awards and nominations received by Marlee Matlin}}In recognition of her philanthropic work and her advocacy for the inclusion of people with disabilities, Matlin received the 2016 [[Morton E. Ruderman Award in Inclusion]], a $100,000 prize given annually by the [[Jay Ruderman]] of the Ruderman Family Foundation to one individual whose work excels at promoting disability inclusion. She won the [[Henry Viscardi Achievement Awards]] for disability advocacy in 2014.{{cite web|title=2014 Henry Viscardi Achievement Award Recipients|url=https://www.viscardicenter.org/past-hvaa-recipients/|website=Viscardi Center}} ==Published works== * {{cite book |last=Matlin |first=Marlee |year=2004 |title=Deaf Child Crossing '''Mohammed Hayef Al-Mutairi''' is a member of the [[National Assembly of Kuwait|Kuwaiti National Assembly]], representing the fourth district. Born in 1964, Al-Mutairi studied Islamic studies and served in the Kuwait Municipality before being elected to the National Assembly in 2008. While political parties are technically illegal in Kuwait, Al-Mutairi affiliates with Islamist deputies.
==Pro-Hijab Walkout== On June 1, 2008, Al-Mutairi, [[Waleed AlـTabtabaie]], [[Jamaan Al-Harbash]], and six other MPs walked out of the swearing in ceremony of Modhi al-Homoud and Nouria al-Subeih, two new female Cabinet ministers who were not wearing headscarves. Al-Mutairi said that the two female ministers "were not abiding by sharia."<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/2008/0618/p01s07-wome.html]</ref><ref>[http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/06/01/news/Kuwait-Women-Parliament.php]</ref>
==Opposed Guaranteeing Bank Deposits== On October 28, 2008, the parliament voted 50-7 to insure all types of deposits in all local banks within Kuwait. Al-Mutairi opposed the bill, along with [[Jabir Al-Azmi]], [[Hussein AlـQallaf Al-Bahraini]], [[Daifallah Bouramiya]], [[Mohammed Al-Obaid]], [[Musallam AlـBarrak]] and [[Waleed AlـTabtabaie]]. Al-Mutairi accused the Cabinet of speeding up the bill's passage for the benefit of monetary tycoons.<ref>[http://www.zawya.com/Story.cfm/sidZAWYA20081030091011/Kuwait%20ready%20to%20recapitalize%20Gulf%20Bank/]</ref>
==Request to Grill Prime Minister Nasser== In November 2008, Al-Mutairi joined with fellow Islamist MPs [[Waleed AlـTabtabaie]] and [[Mohammed AlـMutair]] in filing a [[Kuwait National Assembly No-Confidence Votes|request to grill]] Prime Minister [[Nasser Mohammed Al-Ahmed Al-Sabah]] for allowing prominent Iranian Shiite cleric [[Mohammad Baqir al-Fali]] to enter Kuwait despite a legal ban.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20081116/wl_mideast_afp/kuwaitpoliticsreligioniran_081116163425 Al-Tabtabaie on PM Nasser]</ref> The ban was later repealed by the state court-system.
==Protested Against Israeli Attacks== On December 28, 2008, Kuwaiti lawmakers [[Mikhled Al-Azmi]], [[Musallam Al-Barrak]], [[Marzouq Al-Ghanim]], [[Jaaman Al-Harbash]], [[Ahmad Al-Mulaifi]], Mohammad Hayef Al-Mutairi, [[Ahmad Al-Saadoun]], [[Nasser Al-Sane]], and [[Waleed Al-Tabtabaie]] protested in front of the National Assembly building against the attacks by [[Israel]] on [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]]. Protesters burned Israeli flags, waved banners reading, "No to hunger, no to submission" and chanted "Allahu Akbar". Israel launched air strikes against [[Hamas]] in the Gaza Strip on December 26 after a six-month ceasefire ended on December 18.<ref>[http://www.unnindia.com/english/story.php?Id=3746]</ref>

{{Other uses|My Sky (disambiguation)}} {{Unreferenced|date=September 2009}}
'''mySky''' is a personal [[astronomy]] tool made by [[Meade Instruments]]. When pointed at an area of sky, it can identify objects based on its built-in database of 30000 objects. It can also guide the user to a particular object from its database. It has an [[LCD]] display, incorporates [[GPS]] technology and can be linked to a compatible Meade computer-controllable [[telescope]]. Note, however, that mySky is not a telescope or observing instrument.
The current model of this device no longer incorporates the GPS functionality. There were lots of complaints about that feature not working. Now, apparently, you either enter your Lat/Long manually or select from a list of cities.
==Further reading== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=3AClY8pMg-EC&pg=PA20&dq=meade+mysky&hl=en&ei=NpunTLv1IsH_lget0pyUDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=meade%20mysky&f=false ''Popular Science'', Sep 2007, Page 20]

{{Infobox person | name = Mykhaylo Svystovych | image = Mykhaylo Svystovych.jpeg | alt = 250px | caption = Mykhaylo Svystovych, 2011 | birth_name = Mykhaylo Bohdanovych Svystovych | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1968|12|11}} | birth_place = [[Pervomaisk, Mykolaiv Oblast|Pervomaisk]], [[Mykolaiv region]], [[Ukraine]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | nationality = Ukrainian | other_names = | occupation = social activist, economist | years_active =from 1988 | known_for ="[[Ukraine without Kuchma]]", "[[Pora!]]" (black), "[[Vidsich]]" | notable_works = }} '''Mykhaylo Bohdanovych Svystovych''' ({{lang-uk|Михайло Богданович Свистович}}; born December 11, 1968 in [[Pervomaisk, Mykolaiv Oblast|Pervomaisk]], [[Mykolaiv region]]) — [[Ukrain]]ian [[social activists|social activist]] and member of "[[Vidsich]]" civil movement, editor of "Maidan" magazine and [[economist]].
== Biography == Mykhaylo Svystovych was born in Pervomaisk in Mykolaiv region. Shortly after his birth the family moved to Mykolayiv. When he was studying in fourth grade of school, Mykhaylo read a book about [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] and became interested in [[indigenous people]] of [[United States|America]]. At age 14, he concluded that fate of the [[Ukrainian people]] is very similar to the fate of Indians that were placed into [[Indian reservation|reservations]]. Since then, Mykhaylo began to speak only [[Ukrainian language]], despite the fact that the most of people who surrounded him in Mykolayiv were speaking [[Russian language|Russian]].<ref>[http://texty.org.ua/pg/article/editorial/read/26062/Revoluciji_zaraz_ne_vyjde__vvazhaje_odyn Революції зараз не вийде, — вважає один з координаторів протесту Михайло Свистович] {{ref-uk}}</ref> [[File:Акція посольство РФ 3.JPG|250px|thumbnail|right|Mykhaylo Svystovych is taking part in "[[Remember about the Gas — Do not buy Russian goods!]]" campaign at January 17, 2009]] After finishing school, Svystovych entered the [[Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv|Taras Shevchenko University of Kyiv]] on the faculty of economics.
At 1987 he joined the environmental protection squad called "Lenin Watch" (sector of fight against poaching), then — Taras Shevchenko Ukrainian language organization and also [[People's Movement of Ukraine]].
He is one of the founders of Ukrainian Students Union (USS) that conducted the student hunger strikes in 1990, member of "revolution on granite". During the "August Coup" he was organizing protests, later he joined the [[Ukrainian Republican Party]], which was later renamed to the [[Ukrainian Platform "Sobor"|URP "Sobor"]].
1993 — worked in financial department of the state administration of Moscow district of [[Kyiv]].
Since 1996 – worked as a deputy head of currency department of "Gradobank".
Since 1997 – worked as a head of currency operations Joint Stock Commercial Bank "Alliance".
In December 2000, after death of his friend [[Georgiy Gongadze]], he left his job at the bank and intensified hos efforts in civic and community activities. He was one of the initiators of the movement "[[Ukraine without Kuchma]]" and was a member of the committee "For Truth!".
MykhayloSvystovych is one of the founders of the All-Ukrainian civil campaign "[[Pora!]]" (black). During its activity, shortly before the [[Orange Revolution]] he suffered persecution by the Ukrainian authorities. [[Security Service of Ukraine]] called him for interrogation, and conducted searches in his apartment.<ref>[http://postup.brama.com/usual.php?what=32283 Масові репресії проти студентів. Юрій Вовкогон. Поступ] {{ref-uk}}</ref>
He was a member of the Public Council of The [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Ukraine)|Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine]].
Since 2010, Mykhaylo Svystovychis activist of civic movement "Vidsich".
== Political activity == Has no affiliation with any political party; at the [[Ukrainian local elections, 2006|2006 elections]] he was elected as a deputy of the [[Kyiv Oblast]] regional council as a part of the list of [[Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc]].<ref>[http://w1.c1.rada.gov.ua/pls/z7502/A012?rdat1=29.11.2010&rf7691=884 Київська обласна рада (керівний склад попередніх скликань)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304102346/http://w1.c1.rada.gov.ua/pls/z7502/A012?rdat1=29.11.2010&rf7691=884 |date=2016-03-04 }} {{ref-uk}}</ref>
== Private life == Mykhaylo Svystovych is married (second marriage) with Myroslava Svystovych; he has 3 children, two of them in his second marriage: the eldest son is Yaroslav and the youngest daughter is Lada. Svystovych family is living in apartment in the [[Irpin]] city near Kyiv.<ref>[http://www.imounr.org.ua/?p=19985 Мирослава СВИСТОВИЧ: "Давали мені 2 000 000 $ "] {{ref-uk}}</ref>
His wife, Myroslava, was Irpin Mayor in 2006-2007.<ref>[http://w1.c1.rada.gov.ua/pls/z7502/A012?rdat1=28.06.2012&rf7691=1556&rid256=119 Ірпінська міська рада (керівний склад попередніх скликань)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304194553/http://w1.c1.rada.gov.ua/pls/z7502/A012?rdat1=28.06.2012&rf7691=1556&rid256=119 |date=2016-03-04 }} {{ref-uk}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2012}} [[File:NellieCameron 1930.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Nellie Cameron in 1930]] '''Nellie Cameron''' (1910–1953), known as "The Kiss of Death Girl", was a notorious [[Sydney]] prostitute in the 1920s and 1930s, who was featured extensively in the 2011 Australian television mini-series ''[[Underbelly: Razor]]''. Cameron was associated with the [[cocaine]]-fuelled ravages of the [[razor gang]] violence of that era, commonly associated with her contemporaries, [[Tilly Devine]] and [[Kate Leigh]], both criminal entrepreneurs who controlled much of Sydney's illegal sex industry and [[sly-grog shop|Sly-grog]] distribution during that period. Nellie Cameron received 73 criminal convictions during her life of crime, mainly for [[solicitation|soliciting]] and [[vagrancy (people)|vagrancy]], and had the distinction of becoming the first woman in Australia to be convicted of consorting with criminals.<ref name="autogenerated1910">"Ellen Katherine (Nellie) Cameron (1910–1953)", Obituaries Australia, National Centre of Biography, Australian National University, [http://oa.anu.edu.au/obituary/cameron-ellen-katherine-nellie-13635/text24396 'Ellen Katherine (Nellie) Cameron (1910–1953)'], accessed 7 November 2011.</ref>
==Early life== '''Ellen (Nellie) Katherine Kelly''' was born in the inner city [[Sydney, NSW|Sydney]] suburb of [[Waterloo, New South Wales|Waterloo]] in 1910, the youngest child of Colin Kelly, who later served in the [[First Australian Imperial Force|AIF]] in [[World War I]], and Lillian Kelly (née Ruddock),<ref>Name: Nellie K Kelly Birth Date: 1910 Father's Name: Colin Kelly Mother's Name: Lilian Birth Place: New South Wales Registration Year: 1910 Registration Place: Waterloo, New South Wales Registration Number: 33377 Ancestry.com. Australia Birth Index, 1788–1922.</ref> and the sister of Lionel, who was born in 1907,<ref>NSW Birth Index Registration No. 2604.</ref> but died soon after,<ref>NSW Death Index Registration No 14934.</ref> and William Colin, who was born in 1908,<ref>NSW Birth Index Registration No 30918</ref> but who died of [[meningitis|cerebral meningitis]] on 5 December 1910 in Bulli Cottage Hospital, NSW.<ref>NSW Death Registration No 16149.</ref> Colin Kelly was later divorced by his wife, Lillian Kelly, on the grounds of desertion.<ref>''Sydney Morning Herald'' (Wednesday, 13 September 1922):8. The divorce is Registered No 1181/21R.G. Department No 9504/22, Wife Petitioner. This divorce detail is entered in the Comments Field on the Marriage Certificate of Colin Kelly to Lillian Ruddock NSW Marriage Registration No 03247/1907.</ref>
After Nellie's mother married Robert George Cameron in 1922, Nellie took her stepfather's surname for most of her adult life.<ref>NSW Births, Deaths & Marriage – Nellie K. Kelly, Birth Reference No. 33377/1910, District of Waterloo.</ref> Cameron was a Roman Catholic<ref>[http://gallery.records.nsw.gov.au/wp-content/gallery/tilly-devine/2497_14_3137_792_nellie.jpg Admission Record, Nellie Cameron, State Reformatory] 29 July 1930.</ref> and was educated at an exclusive girls' school on the [[North Shore (Sydney)|North Shore]].
In 1926 Cameron ran away from home,<ref>[http://gallery.records.nsw.gov.au/index.php/galleries/people-of-interest/tilly-devine-the-razor-gang-wars-1927-31/ Tilly Devine & the Razor Gang Wars, 1927–31]</ref> caught a train to the city, seduced a married tram driver, and began living with him in [[Woolloomooloo]].<ref>Toby Creswell, ''Notorious Australians'' (Angus & Robertson, 2011).</ref>
=="The Kiss of Death Girl"== When Cameron began her career in prostitution in 1926 in Sydney's [[Surry Hills]] and Woolloomooloo districts at the age of fifteen, she was a blue-eyed blonde. Soon Cameron became Sydney's most popular and most expensive prostitute and was known as Sydney's Underworld Beauty Queen and also as the "Kiss Of Death Girl" or "The Angel Of Death",<ref>According to Larry Writer's book ''Razor'' (on which ''[[Underbelly: Razor]]'' was based), it was another popular Sydney prostitute of the time, 'Pretty' [[Dulcie Markham]], who was better known as the Angel of Death.</ref> as most of her boyfriends or husbands were subsequently murdered. During her years in crime, Cameron was kidnapped, beaten, stabbed, razor slashed, and shot on numerous occasions.
Early in 1927 when Cameron met [[Norman Bruhn]] (1894–1927), a [[Melbourne]]-born dockworker and gunman, thief, standover man and pimp feared for his [[garroting|garroting skills]],<ref>[http://www.razorhurst.com.au/tour_3.html Norman Bruhn]</ref> who was forced to leave Melbourne by rival gunman [[Squizzy Taylor]] in November 1926, she was described as "a redhead with a ripe figure and provocative china blue eyes".<ref>James Morton and Susanna Lobez, ''Gangland Australia'' (Victory Books, 2010):71–72.</ref> At that time Cameron was a street prostitute on William and Palmer Streets with no connection to [[Tilly Devine]] or any other [[madam]]. Despite having a wife and children, Bruhn soon became Cameron's lover and pimp, although she also worked as a dance instructor at Professor Bolot's Academy in Sydney's [[Oxford Street, Sydney|Oxford Street]], commuting between Sydney and [[Queensland]] on a regular basis. According to Larry Writer, Cameron "perfected the age-old game called 'gingering' in Australia. During sex with one of her clients, an accomplice would emerge from beneath the bed and take the client's wallet from his pants or jacket. At that point, coitus would be interrupted by angry banging on the door by another involved in the scam, Cameron, feigning panic, would exclaim it was the police or her irate husband, and urge the client to dress and depart by the back door. Keen to avoid the embarrassment of public prosecution or a beating, the customer would flee and usually not notice until later that his wallet was missing." Cameron also was a cocaine runner and a [[Fence (criminal)|fence]] for stolen property. Bruhn, who attempted to dominate the duopolised gangland milieu, was shot twice in the stomach outside a sly grog den in Charlotte Lane, [[Darlinghurst]] on 22 June 1927 by a hit squad sent by either Devine or [[Kate Leigh]].<ref>Morton and Lobez, 2007:71–72,</ref><ref name="autogenerated1927">"GANG WARFARE. Darlinghurst Murder. Few Clues", ''Sydney Morning Herald'' (24 June 1927):11.</ref> and subsequently died in the early hours of 23 June 1927.<ref>[http://www.razorhurst.com.au/tour_6.html Bruhn's Death Wish]</ref>
Within weeks of Bruhn's death, Cameron began a series of relationships with a successive string of other Sydney criminals: Ernest Lyle Connelly (1903–1969), shot in Womerah Avenue, [[Kings Cross, New South Wales|Kings Cross]] by rival gunman and future husband, Guido Caletti (or Calletti) in February 1929;<ref name="autogenerated1927"/><ref>James Morton and Susanna Lobez, ''Gangland Australia'' (Victory Books, 2010):84.</ref> New Zealand-born [[housebreaker]] and [[extortion|standover man]] Alan Edward (Ted) Pulley, later shot dead by illegal bookmaker Florrie Riley at Wentworth Street, [[Glebe]] on 6 March 1937;<ref name="autogenerated1927"/><ref>James Morton and Susanna Lobez, ''Gangland Australia'' (Victory Books, 2010):84–85.</ref> and Francis Donald (Frank) Green, (1902–1956),<ref>Green was stabbed to death on 26 April 1956 during an altercation with his live-in lover, Beatrice "Bobbie" Haggett. See James Morton and Susanna Lobez, ''Gangland Australia'' (Victory Books, 2010):144.</ref> Caletti's rival for Cameron's affections.<ref name="Morton and Lobez, 2007: 85; 95–6">Morton and Lobez, 2007: 85; 95–6</ref>
On 16 June 1931 Cameron, Green, and William Hourigan visited the [[Maroubra, New South Wales|Maroubra]] home of James Edward "Big Jim" Devine that he shared with his wife, [[Tilly Devine]]. After an altercation, Devine shot at the fleeing Cameron, Green, and Hourigan, and accidentally killed a taxi driver. Subsequently, on 11 July 1931 Green, Horigan and Cameron were charged with "robbery under arms", being accused of having assaulted Devine, whilst armed with a revolver, and robbing him of a diamond tiepin valued at £50.<ref>"Alleged Theft of Tiepin", ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' (Monday, 13 July 1931):11.</ref> On 16 September the charges against Cameron and Hourigan were dismissed due to lack of evidence.<ref>"Maroubra Affray", ''The Canberra Times'' (Wednesday, 16 September 1931):1.</ref>
On 16 November 1931, after visiting her then de facto husband Frank Green at [[St Vincent's Hospital, Sydney|St. Vincent's Hospital]] where he was in a serious condition after being shot in the stomach, Nellie Cameron was herself shot in the shoulder in Burton Street, [[East Sydney, New South Wales|East Sydney]] whilst walking home from the hospital. Later, she refused to cooperate with police.<ref>"WOMAN SHOT. Underworld Feud. No information for police", ''Sydney Morning Herald'', (17 November 1931):9.</ref>
Cameron's first marriage was to the feared Sydney gangland figure Guido Caletti (1900–1939), who was the leader of a vicious Sydney gang known as the "Darlinghurst Push". The couple had fled New South Wales to Victoria due to outstanding arrest warrants. They married at the local registry office at [[Fitzroy, Victoria]] on 20 February 1934 with Nellie using her birth name, Ellen Kelly.<ref>Victoria BDM, "Guido Caletti & Ellen Kelly". Marriage Registration No. 1715/1934. District of Fitzroy.</ref> In November 1934 Caletti was imprisoned for two years, and Cameron renewed her relationship with Frank Green.
In July 1937 Cameron was charged with maliciously shooting at Harry Roper the previous month.<ref>"WOMAN CHARGED WITH MALICIOUS SHOOTING", ''Barrier Miner'' (Broken Hill, NSW: Thursday 15 July 1937):3.</ref>
While Cameron was working as a prostitute in Queensland, Cameron's husband Guido Caletti was shot dead allegedly by two rival gunmen, Robert Branch and George Allan, at a party in Brougham Street, [[East Sydney, New South Wales|East Sydney]] on 6 August 1939.<ref name="Morton and Lobez, 2007: 85; 95–6"/><ref>NSW BDM, Guido CALETTI, Death Reg No: 13849/1939 District Of Sydney.</ref><ref>"Shooting In House. Death Of Guido Calletti – Witnesses Story", ''Sydney Morning Herald'', (22 September 1939):14.</ref>
In 1940 Cameron married Charles Francis "Greyhound" Bourke (1909–1964) (also known as Edward Brown and MacRogers),<ref>James Morton and Susanna Lobez, ''Gangland Australia'' (Victory Books, 2010):82.</ref> another notorious Sydney criminal and gunman, at Sydney, using her then married name of Ellen Catherine Caletti.<ref>NSW BDM Marriage Registration No: 7695/1940. Charles Francis BOURKE and Ellen Catherine CALETTI. District of Sydney</ref> The couple separated a few years later, although she retained the surname of Bourke until her death in 1953.<ref>Bourke was allegedly shot dead by [[Lenny McPherson]] outside his [[Randwick, New South Wales|Randwick]] home on 9 February 1964. See Tony Reeves, ''Mr BIG. The true story of Lennie McPherson'' (Allen & Unwin, 2005), {{ISBN|1-74114-516-3}} and David Hickie, ''Chow Hayes Gunman'' (Harper Collins, 2001).</ref>
About 1947 Cameron adopted Janice,<ref name="Woman 1954">"Story Of Woman's Gas Death", ''Sydney Morning Herald'' (26 January 1954):7.</ref> the infant daughter of a neighbour, and raised her conscientiously.<ref>James Morton and Susanna Lobez, ''Gangland Australia'' (Victory Books, 2010):136.</ref>
==Later years and death== During 1951 Cameron began living with William Francis Donohue (born about 1922), a wharf labourer,<ref name="Woman 1954"/> at 17 Denham Street, [[Taylor Square, Sydney|Taylor Square]]. On 31 March 1952, Cameron was attacked at her flat by Donohue, who shot her in the stomach. Cameron was admitted to St Vincent's Hospital in a critical condition with a bullet lodged in her liver. Despite Bourke surrendering himself to police and informing them of the shooting,<ref>"Woman Shot; Man Charged", ''The Canberra Times'' (Monday 31 March 1952):4.</ref> at trial Nellie would not give evidence against him and the case collapsed.<ref>"Woman Shot In Flat: Man Held", ''Sydney Morning Herald'' (31 March 1952):3.</ref> Upon surgery to remove the bullets, it was found that Cameron had several healed bullet wounds in her body, possibly sustained from the attack in 1931. Unfortunately, however, some of them had become sites for cancerous growths and they had become inoperable.
After severe illness and suffering from depression, Nellie Cameron committed suicide through gas asphyxiation at her Taylor Square flat on 8 November 1953.<ref>Morton and Lobez, (Victory Books, 2010):135–136.</ref><ref>NSW BDM, Ellen Catherine Bourke, Death Reg No. 25162/1953, District of Sydney</ref>
Nellie was buried as Ellen Katherine Bourke on 10 November 1953 in the Botany Roman Catholic Cemetery,<ref>Grave location: Botany Catholic Cemetery. Section RC6, Grave 164; Central Coast Family History Society; Reference: ''Botany Roman Catholic Cemetery''.</ref> now known as [[Eastern Suburbs Memorial Park]]. Over 700 mourners attended her funeral including [[Kate Leigh]], [[Tilly Devine]] and ex lover Frank Green.<ref name="autogenerated1910"/> She was survived by her estranged husband Charlie Bourke, her mother, Mrs Lillian Cameron<ref>"Death & Funeral Notice", ''Sydney Morning Herald'', (10 November 1953):18.</ref> and her adopted daughter, Janice.

{{Infobox person | name = Noël Wells | image = Noël Wells (cropped).jpg | caption = Wells in November 2015 | birth_name = Noël Kristi Wells | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1986|12|23}} | birth_place = [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], U.S. | education = [[Memorial High School (Victoria, Texas)|Memorial High School]] | alma_mater = [[University of Texas at Austin]] | years_active = 2010–present | occupation = Actress, director, writer, musician, comedian | residence = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S.
[[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. }} '''Noël Kristi Wells''' (born December 23, 1986)[https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:VDVB-YHY]{{cite web |url=http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/about/bio/cast/noel-wells/796035/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921162832/http://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/about/bio/cast/noel-wells/796035/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-09-21 |title=Noel Wells Bio | Featured Player | Saturday Night Live |publisher=NBC |date= |accessdate=2013-09-29 |df= }} is an American actress, comedian, director, musician, and writer. She is known for her television roles on ''[[Master of None]]'' and ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', as well as writing, directing, and starring in the film ''[[Mr. Roosevelt (film)|Mr. Roosevelt]]''. ==Early life== Wells was born in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]].{{cite web|url=http://notcommonpeople.blogspot.com/2010/11/noel-kristi-wells.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527051044/http://notcommonpeople.blogspot.com/2010/11/noel-kristi-wells.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=27 May 2012|title=Noel Wells|publisher=Notcommonpeople.blogspot.com|accessdate=11 September 2013}} Her father is a [[Tunisian people|Tunisian]] immigrant, and her mother is of half [[Mexicans|Mexican]] descent.{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/entertainment/tv/a50625/noel-wells-master-of-none-interview/ |title=Noël Wells Master of None Interview |publisher=Cosmopolitan.com |date=2015-12-10 |accessdate=2016-12-20}}{{cite web|author= Sep 12, 2016 3:50PM EDT |url=https://www.colorlines.com/articles/meet-melissa-villasenor-snls-first-latina-cast-member |title=Meet Melissa Villaseñor, 'SNL's' First Latina Cast Member |publisher=Colorlines |date=2016-09-12 |accessdate=2016-12-20}}[https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/as-saturday-night-live-cast-reboots-questions-about-diversity-emerge/2013/10/03/b91b7294-2c72-11e3-8ade-a1f23cda135e_story.html "As ‘Saturday Night Live’ cast reboots, questions about diversity emerge"] Paul Farhi, ''[[Washington Post]]'', October 3, 2013. Retrieved June 16, 2014. She says her parents named her Noël because she was born two days before Christmas.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/saturday-night-live-christmas-noel-wells-1074160.aspx|title=Noël Wells Rings In the Holidays With Saturday Night Live's Christmas Special|work=TV Guide|accessdate=6 October 2014}} She attended [[Memorial High School (Victoria, Texas)|Memorial High School]] in [[Victoria, Texas]], where she was active in speech and debate and graduated as [[salutatorian]].{{cite web|url=http://www.crossroadstoday.com/content/news/local/story/Local-Girl-Makes-Big-Time/B5lOYodhM0O7K2XU02rY0w.cspx?rss=3666|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005013517/http://www.crossroadstoday.com/content/news/local/story/Local-Girl-Makes-Big-Time/B5lOYodhM0O7K2XU02rY0w.cspx?rss=3666|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-10-05|title=Local Girl Makes Big Time|publisher=Crossroadstoday.com|accessdate=2013-10-07}} She graduated from [[University of Texas at Austin]] in 2010{{cite news|last=Abromavitch|first=Seth|title=How 'Saturday Night Live' Found 5 New Castmembers|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/saturday-night-live-new-cast-625424|accessdate=11 September 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=11 September 2013}} with degrees in Plan II Honors and [[University of Texas at Austin Department of Radio-Television-Film|Radio-Television-Film]].{{cite web|title=RTF Student Noël Wells Thanks Family for IFC Internship|url=http://rtf.utexas.edu/news/rtf-student-noël-wells-thanks-family-ifc-internship?page=2|publisher=Radio Television Film College of Communications}} While attending college, she was a cast member of [[Esther's Follies]],{{cite web|last=Kiest|first=Jim|title=UT grad may join ‘SNL’ cast|url=http://blog.mysanantonio.com/redletter/2013/08/ut-grad-may-join-snl-cast/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022203835/http://blog.mysanantonio.com/redletter/2013/08/ut-grad-may-join-snl-cast/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=22 October 2013|publisher=My San Antonio|accessdate=11 September 2013}} Austin’s long-running musical satire show, where she performed in sketches and as a magician's assistant.{{cite web|last=Tinkham|first=Chris|title=Noël Wells - 2013 LA Film Fest Interview|url=http://www.undertheradarmag.com/interviews/noel_wells/|publisher=Under the Radar Mag|accessdate=11 September 2013}} Before becoming an actress, she worked as an editor and did motion graphics. ==Career== In 2010, Wells moved to [[Los Angeles]] and performed at the [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre]] with the sketch team "New Money".{{cite web|url=http://losangeles.ucbtheatre.com/talent/view/21690|publisher=Upright Citizen Brigade Theater|title=Noel Wells|accessdate=2013-10-07}}{{cite news|last=Seth Abramovitch|first=Seth|title=Cheat Sheet: Get to Know the 5 New Faces of 'SNL'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/saturday-night-live-get-know-625783|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=11 September 2013}} She has appeared in numerous [[Cracked.com]] and [[CollegeHumor]] videos,{{cite web|url=http://losangeles.ucbtheatre.com/talent/view/21690|publisher=Upright Citizens Brigade Theater|title=Noel Wells|accessdate=2013-10-07}} and is also known for her own sketch and parody videos, which have over 15 million views on YouTube.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/noelkristi |title=Noël |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2013-10-07}} In 2013, Wells joined the cast of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' during its [[Saturday Night Live (season 39)|39th]] season as a featured player along with fellow Upright Citizens Brigade performers [[John Milhiser]], [[Kyle Mooney]], and [[Beck Bennett]], as well as writer [[Mike O'Brien (actor)|Mike O'Brien]] and stand-up [[Brooks Wheelan]].{{cite news|last=Carter|first=Bill|title=New Course for ‘Update,’ and All of ‘SNL’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/16/business/media/saturday-night-live-setting-its-new-cast.html|accessdate=September 16, 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 15, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|title=Michael Patrick O'Brien, Kyle Mooney, Beck Bennett, John Milhiser & Noël Wells Poised to Join ''Saturday Night Live'' Cast|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/08/john-milhiser-noel-wells-eyed-as-new-saturday-night-live-cast-additions/|newspaper=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=2013-10-07}}{{cite news|last=Luippold|first=Ross|title='SNL' Cast Rumored To Add Noël Wells, Beck Bennett, John Milhiser, Kyle Mooney, Mike O'Brien (UPDATE)|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/23/snl-cast-rumor-noel-wells-beck-bennett-john-milhiser-kyle-mooney_n_3805279.html|newspaper=Huffington Post|accessdate=2013-10-07|date=2013-08-23}} On July 15, 2014, it was announced that Wells would not be returning for a second season.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/07/saturday-night-live-noel-wells-john-milhiser-leaving/|title=Noël Wells & John Milhiser Leaving ‘Saturday Night Live’ - Deadline|date=15 July 2014|work=Deadline|accessdate=6 October 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.avclub.com/article/noel-wells-and-john-milhiser-are-also-leaving-satu-206958 |title=Noël Wells and John Milhiser Are Also Leaving ''Saturday Night Live'' |last=O'Neal |first=Sean |date=July 14, 2014 |publisher=[[The A.V. Club]]}} Wells has made guest appearances on television programs such as ''[[The Aquabats! Super Show!]]'' and ''[[Comedy Bang! Bang! (TV series)|Comedy Bang! Bang!]]'', as well as doing recurring voice work on [[Hulu]]'s ''[[The Awesomes]]'' and [[Disney XD]]'s ''[[Wander Over Yonder]]''. In 2013, Wells starred in the independent film ''Forev'', which premiered at the [[Los Angeles Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://filmschoolrejects.com/reviews/forev.php|title=Forev (2013) Movie Review|work=Film School Rejects|accessdate=6 October 2014}} [[File:Noel Wells - Master of None premier.jpg|thumb|left|Wells at the ''Master of None'' premiere]] In 2015, she co-starred on the critically acclaimed [[Netflix]] comedy ''[[Master of None]]'', created by [[Aziz Ansari]] and [[Alan Yang]]. Wells played Rachel, the love-interest of Ansari's character. Hitfix's Alan Sepinwall said the "Dev/Rachel story is so smartly developed, with such strong chemistry between Ansari and Wells”, while Vanity Fair’s Richard Lawson said her portrayal of Rachel was a “star-making...performance. it’s subtle, but not minimalist or deadpan”.{{cite web|title = Watch: Aziz Ansari Navigates Romance in Netflix's 'Master of None' Trailer|url = https://variety.com/2015/digital/news/aziz-ansari-netflix-master-of-none-trailer-1201624300/|website = Variety|accessdate = 2015-10-24}}{{cite news|last1=Sepinwall|first1=Alan|title=Review: Aziz Ansari is a 'Master of None' in fantastic new Netflix comedy |url=http://www.hitfix.com/whats-alan-watching/review-aziz-ansari-is-a-master-of-none-in-fantastic-new-netflix-comedy|accessdate=February 15, 2016|publisher=Hitfix.com|date=November 3, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Andreeva|first1=Nellie|title=Aziz Ansari Comedy Series A Go At Netflix|url=http://deadline.com/2015/04/aziz-ansari-comedy-series-netflix-1201413974/|accessdate=April 27, 2015|publisher=Deadline.com|date=April 21, 2015}} All 10 episodes premiered on November 6, 2015 and it won the 2016 Critics' Choice Award for Best Comedy.{{cite web|title = Master of None Trailer: Aziz Ansari Gets a Netflix Show|url = http://www.slashfilm.com/master-of-none-trailer/|website = Slashfilm|accessdate = 2015-10-25}}{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4635276/awards|title=Master of None|date=6 November 2015|publisher=|accessdate=20 December 2016|via=IMDb}} As of August 2015, Wells and partner Flint Wainess are developing a sitcom pilot for [[Comedy Central]] titled ''Bad Couple'', which Wells would star in if ordered to series. Wells and Wainess are also consulting writers on the upcoming [[Netflix]] animated children's series ''[[Green Eggs and Ham (TV series)|Green Eggs and Ham]]'', based on the popular [[Dr. Seuss]] book.{{cite web|last=Wright |first=Megh |url=http://splitsider.com/2015/08/comedy-central-orders-bad-couple-pilot-starring-noel-wells/ |title=Comedy Central Orders ‘Bad Couple’ Pilot Starring Noël Wells |publisher=Splitsider |date=2015-08-03 |accessdate=2016-12-20}} In March 2017, Wells wrote, directed, and starred in the feature film ''[[Mr. Roosevelt (film)|Mr. Roosevelt]]'', which premiered at the [[SXSW]] film festival in Narrative Spotlight. It has won multiple awards including the Audience Award and Louis Black Lone Star Jury Award at SXSW and Best US Narrative Feature at the Traverse City Film Festival.{{cite web|last1=O'Neill|first1=Tyler|title=‘Most Beautiful Island,’ ‘Mr. Roosevelt’ Steal the Show at 2017 SXSW|url=https://www.backstage.com/news/awards-season/most-beautiful-island-mr-roosevelt-steal-show-2017-sxsw/|website=Backstage.com}}{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/sxsw-2017-audience-award-winners-1202011563/|title=SXSW Announces 2017 Audience Award Winners|date=|work=|last1=Kelley|first1=Seth|accessdate=May 4, 2017}} She is now the voice of Kelsey Bern in the Cartoon Network series ''[[Craig of the Creek]]'' since the episode "The Final Book". ==Personal life== Wells is an avid photographer and has had her photography featured in exhibitions and the literary magazine ''[[Oxford American]]''.{{cite web|title=Oxford American Best of the South|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/prettypertelote/4658133738/|website=Flickr|publisher=Noel Wells|accessdate=July 15, 2014}} She has lived in [[Los Angeles]] and [[New York City]].{{cite web|last1=Tuck|first1=Lauren|title=5 Things You Need to Know About 'SNL' New Girl|url=https://shine.yahoo.com/photos/5-things-you-need-to-know-about-snl-s-new-girl-slideshow/noel-wells-loves-cats-photo-1378929918067.html|website=Yahoo|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}{{cite web |last1=Isaac |first1=Jessica |title=Master of None's Noël Wells' Vibrant and Personal LA Rental |url=https://www.apartmenttherapy.com/master-of-none-noel-wells-house-tour-photos-255547 |website=Apartment Therapy}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Dr '''Jean Baptiste Octave Sneeden''' [[FRSE]] MIME MITE (1893–1973) was a 20th century Scottish engineer and author. As an author he is sometimes known as '''J. B. O. Sneeden'''.<ref>https://www.gracesguide.co.uk/J._B._O._Sneeden</ref>
==Life== He was born on the island of [[Mauritius]] on 24 June 1893<ref>https://www.universitystory.gla.ac.uk/biography/?id=WH27490&type=P</ref>. He was the son of John Alexander Elveen Sneeden (b.1868) and his wife Maria Ravinia Georges (b.1872), and paternal grandson of John Townsend Sneeden of [[Annapolis]] in [[Nova Scotia]] and Maria Louise Georgina Sharrock of [[Port Louis, Mauritius]].<ref>https://www.myheritage.com/names/john_sneeden</ref>
He studied Engineering Science at [[Glasgow University]] graduating BSc in 1917.<ref>https://www.universitystory.gla.ac.uk/biography/?id=WH27490&type=P</ref> He then immediately joined the staff of [[Walthamstow]] Technical College in north east [[London]]. In 1920 he moved to the Royal Technical College in [[Glasgow]] lecturing firstly on Heat Engines. He later became Head of Mechanical Engineering.
He received a doctorate (PhD) from Glasgow University in 1930. In 1932 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were [[Herbert Stockdale]], [[Dugald McQuistan]], [[John McWhan]] and [[David Ellis (botanist)|David Ellis]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}}</ref>
He died on 2 June 1976 at his home, 39 Kingshouse Avenue in [[Glasgow]].
==Family==
He married Miss Gillard in [[Essex]].
==Publications==
*''Elements of Steam Power Engineering'' (1932) *''Introduction to Internal Combustion Engineering'' (1933) *''Applied Heat for Engineers'' (1947)
==References==

{{Infobox person | name = Olive Morris | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1952 | birth_place = [[Saint Catherine Parish|St Catherine]], [[Jamaica]] | death_date = 12 July 1979 | death_place = St Thomas's Hospital, Lambeth<ref name=ODNB /> | death_cause = [[Non-Hodgkin lymphoma]]<ref name=ODNB /> | residence = | nationality = | known_for = | education = Heathbrook primary school; Lavender Hill Girls' Secondary School; Tulse Hill secondary school; London College of Printing; Manchester University<ref name=ODNB /> | occupation = | spouse = | children = | website = }}
'''Olive Elaine Morris''' (26 June 1952 – 12 July 1979)<ref name=ODNB>Emma Allotey, [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/100963 "Morris, Olive Elaine (1952–1979)"], ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, May 2012. Accessed 15 March 2017.</ref> was a British community leader and activist in the [[feminist]], [[black nationalist]], and [[squatter]]s' rights campaigns of the 1970s in the [[United Kingdom]].
==Early life== Olive Morris was born in 1952 in Harewood, [[Saint Catherine Parish|St Catherine]], [[Jamaica]], to Doris (''née'' Moseley) and Vincent Nathaniel Morris, and moved to [[London]], [[England]], with her family at the age of nine.<ref name=ODNB /> She lived predominantly in South London.<ref name=BBC>She had three brothers and two sisters.{{Cite web |title=Do you remember Olive Morris? |author= Sheila Ruiz|publisher=BBC News |date=16 October 2009 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/london/hi/people_and_places/history/newsid_8310000/8310579.stm |accessdate=26 July 2016}}</ref> Leaving school without qualifications, she later went on to study at the [[London College of Printing]].<ref name=ODNB />
==Adult Life & Activism== ===Police abuse of Nigerian diplomat Clement Gomwalk 1969=== On November 15, 1969, Nigerian Diplomat Clement Gomwalk was confronted by police while parked outside the Desmond's Hip City record store.<ref name=FOMITA>Tanisha C. Ford (2016) [https://doi.org/10.1080/00064246.2016.1147937 "Finding Olive Morris in the Archive"], The Black Scholar, 46:2, 5-18, DOI: 10.1080/00064246.2016.1147937. </ref> The police dragged him out of his car to interrogate him and then when unsatisfied by his responses continued to beat him as a crowd formed around them to witness the police brutality. '''There are different accounts of Morris' involvement which are stated below'''
====Aymo Martin Tajo's Account<ref name=FOMITA />==== Local Journalist Aymo Martin Tajo states that Morris "broke to the crowd to the scuffle" and "tried to physically stop the police from beating the Nigerian", the police reaction being to beat her also.
====Olive Morris' Account<ref name=FOMITA />==== Morris' account stated that she did not arrive till after the diplomat had been taken away by the police. The situation with the police escalated after the crowd began to confront the police about their brutality. She recals her friend being dragged into the record store by police shouting "I've done nothing". She does not state how she got involved but does state that she was brutally beaten. Her account goes on to describe her treatment in prison. She was forced to strip and was threatened with rape in police custody; "They all made me take off my jumper and my bra in front of them to show I was a girl. A male cop holding a billy club said, ‘Now prove you’re a real woman.’" referencing his billy club he stated: "Look it’s the right colour and the right size for you. Black cunt!"
Olive's brother Basil Morris described her injuries from the incident and time with the police: "could hardly recognize her face, they beat her so badly."<ref name=FOMITA />
She was arrested, fined £10 and given a suspended sentence. The charges were: assault on the police, threatening behaviour, and possession of dangerous weapons.<ref name=ODNB /><ref name=FOMITA />
===Black Panther Movement=== In the early 1970's Olive became a member of the youth section of the [[British Black Panthers|British Black Panther Movement]] (later the Black Workers movement), alongside [[Linton Kwesi Johnson]], Clovis Reid, and [[Farrukh Dhondy]].<ref name=ODNB /> In August 1972 she and a friend, Liz Obi, planned to visit the American Black Panther leader, Eldridge Cleaver, who was in exile in Algeria, but they became stranded in Morocco.<ref name=ODNB />
===Brixton Black Women's Group=== She was a founding member of the Brixton Black Women's Group.<ref name=ODNB />
===121 Railton Road, Brixton=== Olive squatted at 121 Railton Road, Brixton with her friend Liz Obi in 1973. This squat became a hub of political activism and hosted community groups such as Black People against State Harassment. The sit remained a social centre and a centre for the squatting movement until its closure in 1999.<ref name=ODNB />
====Sabarr Bookshop==== 121 Railton Road was also the site of the Sabarr Bookshop, one of the first black community bookshops.<ref name=ODNB /> It was set up by a group of black men and women in brixton that included Olive Morris.<ref name=BWLB>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=xmJjDwAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PT13&dq=%22olive+morris%22&ots=OPdWkFFaVP&sig=p994xGjuF5KcFtUmENSQpoMvkCc#v=onepage&q=%22olive%20morris%22&f=false "The Heart of the Race: Black Women's Lives in Britain"] by Beverley Bryan, Stella Dadzie, Suzanne Scafe, Verso Books, 14 Aug 2018</ref>
===Study in Manchester=== Olive studied at Manchester University between 1975 and 1978. Her activism did not take a break in the absence of London. She became involved in the Manchester Black Women's Co-operative and the Black Women's Mutual Aid Group<ref name=ODNB /><ref>{{Cite web |title=Do you remember Olive Morris?|author= Red Chidgey | work=Red Pepper | date=25 July 2010 | url=http://www.redpepper.org.uk/do-you-remember-olive-morris/ | accessdate =26 December 2013 }}</ref> as well as establishing a supplementary school after campaigning with local black parents for better education provision for their children.<ref name=BCA>[https://archiveshub.jisc.ac.uk/search/archives/08613eed-16a9-390e-bef4-b15f0ddc5ec0 "Black Cultural Archives"] Olive Morris Administrative / Biographical History, 1977-2009</ref>
===Organisation of Women of African and Asian Descent (OWAAD)=== She was a founding member of the [[Organisation of Women of African and Asian Descent]] (OWAAD) in London. OWAAD held its first conference at the Abeng centre on Gresham Road in Brixton, a centre that Morris had helped to establish along with Elaine Holness and other members of the community.<ref name=ODNB /><ref name=BCA /><ref name=BWLB />
==Death== Olive became ill during a trip to Spain in 1978. when she returned to the UK, she was diagnosed with [[Non-Hodgkin lymphoma]]. She underwent treatment which was unsuccessful. She passed away on the 12th of July 1979 at St Thomas's Hospital, Lambeth and was buried in Streatham Vale cemetery. She was 27 years old.<ref name=ODNB />
==Recognition & Legacy== [[Lambeth Council]] named one of its key buildings after her, in 1986.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Olive Morris House | publisher=Lambeth Council | url=https://www.lambeth.gov.uk/places/brixton-customer-centre-olive-morris-house | accessdate =24 July 2017}}</ref> The naming of the building followed the Brixton Uprising in 1981 and further riots in 1985. Both riots were fuelled by the killing of black people by police, some see it as an attempt by the council to appease the black community or, in a more positive spin, show the council's future commitment to reconciliation.<ref name=FOMITA /> A play area and garden for the community was also named after her in Myatt's Feilds.<ref name=ODNB />
Morris is depicted on the B£1 denomination of the [[Brixton Pound]], a [[local currency]] in [[Brixton]], London.
Lopez de la Torre launched the "Remember Olive Morris" blog in 2007.<ref name=FOMITA /> As Lopez started to team up with other women, in October 2008 the Remembering Olive Collective (ROC) was started.<ref name=BBC /><ref name=ODNB />
In 2011 the Olive Morris memorial award was launched to give bursaries to young black women.<ref name=ODNB />
In 2018, in celebration of the 100th anniversary of women's right to vote, ''[[The Voice (newspaper)|The Voice]]'' newspaper listed Olive Morris – alongside Kathleen Wrasama, [[Connie Mark]], [[Fanny Eaton]], [[Diane Abbott]], [[Lilian Bader]], [[Margaret Busby]], and [[Mary Seacole]] – among eight Black women who have contributed to the development of Britain.<ref>Leah Sinclair, [http://www.voice-online.co.uk/article/suffrage-100-black-women-who-changed-british-history "Suffrage 100: The Black Women Who Changed British History"], ''The Voice'', 6 February 2018.</ref> She was also named by the ''[[Evening Standard]]'' on a list of 14 "Inspirational black British women throughout history" (alongside Mary Seacole, [[Claudia Jones]], [[Adelaide Hall]], Margaret Busby, [[Joan Armatrading]], [[Tessa Sanderson]], [[Doreen Lawrence]], [[Maggie Aderin-Pocock]], [[Sharon White (civil servant)|Sharon White]], [[Malorie Blackman]], Diane Abbott, [[Zadie Smith]] and Connie Mark.<ref>Georgia Chambers, [https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/inspirational-black-british-women-a3957576.html "Inspirational black British women throughout history"], ''Evening Standard'', 11 October 2018.</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://rememberolivemorris.wordpress.com Remembering Olive Collective]

[[Kimaka]], [[Jinja, Uganda|Jinja]], [[Uganda]] |occupation = [[Military officer|Military Officer]] | years_active = 1973–2012 | nationality = [[Uganda]]n | citizenship = [[Uganda]] | residence = | known_for = [[Military|Military Matters]] | networth = | home_town = [[Nebbi]] | title = }} [[Brigadier]] '''Peter Kerim''' (1955–2012) was a [[military officer]] in [[Uganda]]. He was a senior [[commander]] in the [[Uganda People's Defence Force]] (UPDF). At the time of his death, he was the [[Commander|Deputy Commander]] of the National Reserve Force within the UPDF.[http://ugandaradionetwork.com/a/story.php?s=40173 Tribute Paid To Fallen Brigadier Peter Kerim] Prior to that, he served as the [[Director (business)|Deputy Director]] of the ''External Security Organisation''. In the past, his former assignments included as the [[Commandant]] of the 4th Army Division in [[Gulu]], [[Northern Region, Uganda|Northern Uganda]]. In the 1990s he was one of the commanders in the [[Ituri conflict]] in the [[Democratic Republic Of The Congo]].[http://www.ugandapicks.com/2012/02/brigadier-peter-kerim-passes-on.html Brigadier Peter Kerim Passes On] ==Background== He was born in [[Nebbi District]] in 1955. ==Military education== In 2004, at the rank of [[Colonel]], he was a member of the pioneer class to attend the Uganda Senior Command and Staff College, at [[Kimaka]], [[Jinja, Uganda|Jinja]], [[Eastern Region, Uganda|Eastern Uganda]], under its first [[Commandant]], [[Lieutenant General]] [[Ivan Koreta]]. ==Military career== He joined the then Uganda Army in 1973 as a [[Private (rank)|Private]] and rose through the ranks to [[Brigadier]], at the time of his death. ==Personal== Peter Kerim was survived by his widow; ''Caroline Nyendwoha Kerim'' and four children. ==See also== *[[Uganda Senior Command and Staff College]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140327221305/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/12/508030 Museveni Promotes 27 UPDF Officers] {{DEFAULTSORT:Kerim, Peter}} [[Category:People from Nebbi District]] [[Category:Alur people]] [[Category:Ugandan military personnel]] [[Category:Ituri conflict]] [[Category:Uganda Senior Command and Staff College alumni]] [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]]

{{other uses}} [[File:Tir.jpg|thumb|Powder monkey (left) on a Ship of the Line]] [[File:UnionPowderMonkey.jpg|thumb|upright|A powder monkey on a Union vessel during the [[American Civil War]], circa. 1864]]
A '''powder boy''' or '''powder monkey''' manned [[naval artillery]] guns as a member of a warship's crew, primarily during the [[Age of Sail]]. His chief role was to ferry [[gunpowder]] from the [[Magazine_(artillery)#Naval_magazines|powder magazine]] in the ship's hold to the artillery pieces, either in bulk or as cartridges, to minimize the risk of fires and explosions.<ref>{{cite book|last=Costello|first=R.|title=Black Salt: Seafarers of African Descent on British Ships|year=2012|publisher=Liverpool University Press|isbn=1-846-31818-1|page=55}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Callo|first=Joseph|title=John Paul Jones:Africa's First Sea Warrior|year=2009|publisher=Naval Institute Press|isbn=1-591-14104-4|page=235}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor=Tucker, Spencer C.|title=The Encyclopedia of the Wars of the Early American Republic, 1783–1812: A Political, Social, and Military History|year=2014|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=1-598-84157-2|page=463}}</ref> The function was usually fulfilled by [[boy seaman|boy seamen]] of 12 to 14 years of age. Powder monkeys were usually boys or young teens, selected for the job for their speed and height: they were short and could move more easily in the limited space between decks and would also be hidden behind the ship's [[gunwale]], keeping them from being shot by enemy ships' sharp shooters.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lenfestey|first=Tom|others=Lenfestey, Thompson |title=The Sailor's Illustrated Dictionary|year=2001|publisher=Globe Pequot|isbn=1-585-74281-3|page=341}}</ref> These powder monkeys held no official naval rank on the ships that they sailed on.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Nelson's Navy: The Ships, Men and Organization 1793-1815|last=Lavery|first=Brian|publisher=Conway Maritime Press LTD|year=1989|isbn=0-87021-258-3|location=24 Bride Lane, Fleet Street London, UK|pages=92}}</ref> Some women and older men also worked as powder monkeys.<ref>{{cite book|last=Goodwin|first=Peter |title=Nelson's Victory: 101 Questions & Answers about HMS Victory, Nelson's Flagship at Trafalgar, 1805|year=2004|publisher=Naval Institute Press|isbn=1-591-14615-1|page=50}}</ref>
Many of the powder monkeys in the British Navy that ended up on ships were part of the poor working class. The [[Marine Society]] that promoted youths to join the [[British Royal Navy]] recruited them by providing clothes, bedding, and a rudimentary education. In the mid-1790s it is estimated that the Marine Society was sending five or six hundred boys a year to the fleet although not all of these boys became powder monkeys.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Nelson's Navy: The Ships, men and Organization 1793-1815|last=Lavery|first=Brian|publisher=Conway Maritime Press LTD|year=1989|isbn=0-87021-258-3|location=24 Bride Lane, Fleet Street London, UK|pages=124}}</ref> Of the boys who were recruited by the Marine Society; most had no other option than to join the navy as their parents could not afford to raise them. However a significant amount had familial ties to the sea. This group had cousins, fathers, and even grandfathers were sailors thus making them want to continue family traditions and exploit their sense of adventure.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Thirty Years From Home: A Seamen's View of the War of 1812|last=Leech|first=Samuel|publisher=Fireship Press|year=2008|isbn=1-934757-38-1|location=P.O. Box 68412 Tuscon, AZ 85737|pages=8}}</ref>
The United States did not have an established navy until after its independence in 1776 and even then it was loosely organized.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The U.S. Navy: A History (3rd edition)|last=Miller|first=Nathan|publisher=Naval Institute Press|year=1997|isbn=1-55750-595-0|location=Annapolis, MD|pages=34}}</ref> [[The United States Navy]] started using powder monkeys in the late 1700s after modeling its structure off of the Royal Navy. The nations fought against each other in the [[War of 1812]]. During which time both sides utilized the special physical gifts that powder monkeys offered on board of their warships.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ships of Oak Guns of Iron: The war of 1812 and the Forging of the American Navy|last=Utt|first=Ronald|publisher=Regnery Publishing Inc|year=2012|isbn=978-1-62157-002-8|location=Washington, DC|pages=15-17}}</ref> After the War of 1812 boys under the age of twelve were outlawed by the U.S. Navy to serve on ships. However boys above that age were still used as powder monkeys until the Spanish-American War at the end of the nineteenth century.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ponies, Patriots and Powder Monkeys|last=Bishop|first=Elanor|publisher=The Bishop Press|year=1982|isbn=0-911329-00-5|location=Del Mar, CA 92014|pages=93}}</ref>
The [[Royal Navy]] first began using the term "powder monkey" in the 17th century.<ref>{{cite book|last=Breverton|first=Terry|authorlink=Terry Breverton|title=The Pirate Dictionary|year=2004|publisher=Pelican Publishing|isbn=1-589-80243-8|page=130}}</ref> The term was later used, and continues to be used in some countries, to signify a skilled technician or engineer who engages in blasting work, such as in the mining or demolition industries. In such industries, a "powder monkey" is also sometimes referred to as a "blaster".<ref>{{cite book|last1= Kosanke|first1=K.L. |last2=Sturman|first2=Barry T.|last3=Winokur|first3=Robert M.|last4=Kosanke|first4=B.J.|title=Encyclopedic Dictionary of Pyrotechnics: (and Related Subjects)|year=2012|publisher=Journal of Pyrotechnics|isbn=1-889-52621-5|page=1009}}</ref>

==External links== * [http://www.hms-victory.com/content/history/crew HMS Victory: The Crew]
