{{multiple image |image1=Fremont Solstice Parade 2011 - staging area 20A.jpg|caption1=Purple Mark at the 2011 [[Fremont Solstice Parade]].|width1=178 |image2=Fremont Fair 2007 Purple Mark in green.jpg|caption2=Purple Mark at the 2007 [[Fremont Solstice Parade]]. He is wearing a wig in this picture.}} '''Mark Wirth''', better known as '''Purple Mark''', is a [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]] resident, "fashion notable"<ref name=Jonjak>{{cite news |first=Marti |last=Jonjak |url=http://slog.thestranger.com/slog/archives/2012/10/09/fashion-notable-purple-mark |title=Fashion Notable: Purple Mark |work=Slog |publisher=blog of ''[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]'' |date=October 9, 2012 |accessdate=December 17, 2012}}</ref> who has become locally famous, especially around the [[Capitol Hill (Seattle)|Capitol Hill]] neighborhood where he lives, for his colorful attire and his equally colorful dyed hair and beard.<ref name=Jonjak /><ref name=Murakami>{{cite news |first=Keri |last=Murakami |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/article/Purple-Mark-makes-his-mark-on-Capitol-Hill-1239383.php |title=Purple Mark makes his mark on Capitol Hill |work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer |date=June 1, 2007 |accessdate=December 17, 2012}}</ref><ref name=Dials>{{cite news |first=Amy |last=Dials |url=http://blogs.seattleweekly.com/threadcount/2007/05/seattles_purple_mark_tells_all.php |title=Seattle's "Purple Mark" Tells All! |work=[[Seattle Weekly]] Blog |date=May 29, 2007 |accessdate=December 17, 2012}}</ref> He has been quoted as saying, "So many people are against color, so many people are afraid to live."<ref name=Dials />
Purple Mark usually dresses and dyes his hair, beard and other hair on his body, such as on his eyebrows and arm-hair, in accord with the cycle of the seasons: blue and purple in the winter, then the weather warms up green, yellow, and orange, then red in the autumn before cycling back to his winter colors.<ref name=Murakami /> The process of applying the dye takes about four hours when he changes color, with two hours every two weeks for touch-up for "vibrancy."<ref name=Jonjak /> He also attempts to eat and drink along a similar pattern of color.<ref name=Murakami /> By his own account, the name "Purple Mark" predates his colorful self-presentation, dating back to when he was hit by a purple streak of lightning on [[Mount Sneffels]] in Colorado at age 11.<ref name=Murakami /> He moved to Seattle in 1985.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} He has said he was first influenced to dye his hair by the wild styles he saw around [[Pike Place Market]], but soon went well beyond the street fashion of the time to develop his unique look.<ref name=Murakami /> On another occasion he explained his rainbow tones as originally springing from observation of the sun's rays coming through his eyelids: "Your vision attempts to correct this color to white, and some hair had fallen across my eyes, so when I opened them, my hair appeared bright green. I thought to myself: 'I'm gonna do that.'"<ref name=Jonjak />
From 1994 to at least 2007, he worked in the [[Ballard, Seattle|Ballard]] neighborhood in what was basically an [[assembly line]] job at motor oil and fuel additives company [[Bardahl]].<ref name=Murakami /> Most of his wardrobe is purchased second-hand or made by himself.<ref name=Jonjak /><ref name=Cohen>{{cite AV media |first=Ari Seth |last=Cohen |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oh6AiPyFYEw |title=PurpleMarkSeattle |type=short documentary film |date=August 3, 2012 |accessdate=December 17, 2012}} Also available as ''[http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Video?show=14986139 Advanced Style: Seattle's Purple Mark]'' on the site of ''The Stranger'', dated October 10, 2012.</ref> He brings a variety of techniques to making his own outfits, ranging from dying human-hair wigs to [[metalsmithing]], in which he has a degree.<ref name=Cohen />

'''Richard M. Bowen III''' is an American banker who [[Whistleblowers|blew the whistle]] on [[mortgage fraud]] at [[Citigroup]] that helped trigger the [[sub-prime mortgage crisis]].
A senior vice president at Citigroup, Bowen served as the chief underwriter of the [[financial services]] conglomerate's Consumer Lending Group. Bowen's responsibility was essentially to serve as the quality control supervisor ensuring the unit's creditworthiness. Beginning in June 2006, Bowen began warning the board of directors about the extreme risks being taken on by the mortgage operation that could potentially result in massive losses.
His group bought and sold $90 billion of residential mortgages annually. When Bowen first blew the whistle in 2006, 60% of the mortgages were defective. The amount of bad mortgages began increasing throughout 2007 and eventually exceeded 80% of the volume. Many of the mortgages were not only defective, but [[Mortgage fraud|were fraudulent]].
Bowen attempted to rouse the board via weekly reports and other communications. On 3 November 2007, Bowen emailed Citigroup Chairman Robert Rubin and the bank's [[chief financial officer]], head auditor and the risk management officer to again expose the risk and potential losses, claiming that the group's internal controls had broken down. He requested an outside investigation of his business unit. The investigation revealed that Bowen was right, and that the Consumer Lending Group had suffered a breakdowns of internal controls since 2005,
Bowen's warnings were ignored, despite the fact that withholding such information from shareholders violated the [[Sarbanes-Oxley Act]], which he pointed out. Despite his warnings, Citigroup CEO [[Charles Prince]] signed a certification that the bank was in compliance with the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.
Citigroup stripped Bowen of most of his responsibilities and informed him that his physical presence was no longer required at the bank. The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission asked him to testify about Citigroup's role in the mortgage crisis, and he did so, appearing as one of the first witnesses before the Commission in April 2010.<ref name="Prosecuting Wall Street">{{cite web|title=Prosecuting Wall Street|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-18560_162-57336042/prosecuting-wall-street/|publisher=CBS News: 60 Minutes|accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref><ref name="Richard Bowen Bio">{{cite web|title=Richard Bowen: Bio|url=http://www.richardmbowen.com/title:bio|work=|publisher=Richard Bowen:Citigroup Whistleblower & Speaker on Accountable Leadership|accessdate=23 September 2013}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=7390542n ''Prosecuting Wall Street'', pt. 2], CBS News, ''60 Minutes''

{{BLP sources|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Robert Roche | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Robert Joseph Roche | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|05|03}}{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/apr/4/native-americans-others-protest-indians-logo/ |title=Native Americans, others protest Indians' logo |work=The Washington Times |first= |last= |date=4 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.clevescene.com/cleveland/native-cleveland-robert-roche-and-the-origins-of-american-indian-activism-in-cleveland/Content?oid=4386043&showFullText=true |title=Native Cleveland: Robert Roche and the Origins of American Indian Activism in Cleveland |work=Cleveland Scene |first=Sam |last=Allard |date=1 October 2014 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} | birth_place = [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], [[US]] | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = [[Parma, Ohio]] | nationality = [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indian]] | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Civil rights]] organizer | years_active = 1973–present | organization = The American Indian Education Center
People, Not Mascots
Autonomous American Indian Movement (AAIM) | known_for = Chairman and Executive Director of the American Indian Education Center of Cleveland
Opposition to [[Chief Wahoo]] and other [[Native American mascot controversy|Native American mascots]] | relatives = | awards = | website = }} '''Robert Roche''', also known as '''Bob Roche''' and '''Rob Roche''', is a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] civil rights activist. He is perhaps best known for being one of several prominent American Indians to spearhead the movement against the use of [[Native American mascot controversy|Native American imagery]] as sports mascots. ==Early life== Robert Roche was born Robert Joseph Roche on 3 May 1947 at Saint Ann's Hospital located in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]]. Robert is a member of the [[Chiricahua|Chiricahua Apache]], a tribe of the Apache living in the Southwestern part of the United States.{{cite web |url=http://nativenewsonline.net/currents/cleveland-american-indian-education-centers-robert-roche-dont-honor-us/ |title=Cleveland American Indian Education Center’s Robert Roche: "Don’t Honor Us!" |work=Native News Online |first=Levi |last=Rickert |date=7 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}} He would end up meeting [[Russell Means]], a well-known actor, civil rights activist and founder of the [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]] branch of the [[American Indian Movement]]. He would profoundly influence a young Roche, and the two would go on to collaborate on many projects. ==Career== From 1974 to 1984, Roche worked in the City of Cleveland Juvenile Court Division as an Acting Probation Officer. During this time, he worked with indigenous youth who had come in contact with and were already in the juvenile justice system.{{cite web |url=https://www.udayton.edu/artssciences/graul_chair/rrw/resources/documents/roche_profile.pdf |title=Robert Roche |work=University of Dayton |first=Robert |last=Roche |date= |accessdate=11 October 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mountunion.edu/robert-roche-to-discuss-american-indian-movement |title=Robert Roche to Discuss American Indian Movement |work=Mount Union |first=Abby |last=Honaker |date=8 November 2010 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} In 1995, Robert Roche founded the American Indian Education Center, a non-profit organization that offered a variety of re-entry services for the American Indian population in the greater [[Greater Cleveland]] area, including HIV testing, tutoring, smoking cessation classes, cultural programming and resume writing instruction.{{cite web |url=http://www.netzkraft.net/mitglied.php?teilnehmer=1488&lang=englisch |title=American Indian Education Center (AIEC) |work=NetzKraft |first= |last= |date= |accessdate=20 June 2014}} in [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]], [[Ohio]].{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/naymik/index.ssf/2014/07/robert_roche_battles_chief_wah.html |title=Robert Roche battles Chief Wahoo, the Cleveland Indians and troubles of his own: Mark Naymik |work=NetzKraft |first=Mark |last=Naymik |date=2 July 2014 |accessdate=5 July 2014}} Roche opened the American Indian Education Center to provide a more comprehensive variety of services after the two decades of controversy its "predecessor," the Cleveland American Indian Center, founded by [[Russell Means]], had been embroiled in. in [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]], [[Ohio]].{{cite web |url=http://ech.case.edu/cgi/article.pl?id=CAIC |title=CLEVELAND AMERICAN INDIAN CENTER - The Encyclopedia of Cleveland |work=Case Western Reserve University |first= |last= |date=5 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}}
Robert currently serves as the executive director of the American Indian Education Center in [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]], [[Ohio]].{{cite web |url=http://article.wn.com/view/2014/04/05/Native_American_group_protests_Chief_Wahoo/ |title=Native American group protests Chief Wahoo |work=NetzKraft |first= |last= |date=5 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}} Some of the work he carried out was documented in a book written by attorney Joseph Patrick Meissner as part of a compendium of accounts focusing on people who work to improve their community.{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Uc_fAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA544&lpg=PA544&dq=russell+means+robert+roche&source=bl&ots=m60MZ4q7LZ&sig=C-gnMS9OzBqDhzF-qt8vcCmKOZg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8D66U7boG42gqAbL04KQAw&ved=0CEcQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=russell%20means%20robert%20roche&f=false |title=The Legal Warriors |work=The Legal Warriors |first=Joseph Patrick |last=Meissner, J.D. |date=13 September 2013 |accessdate=7 July 2014}} Robert Roche has also taught a course in Oberlin College's Experimental College Department about the history of the [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] civil rights organization, the [[American Indian Movement]].{{cite web |url=http://www.oberlin.edu/stuorg/exco/students/oldcourses/spring06.htm |title=Course Offerings |work=Oberlin Course Offerings |first= |last= |date= |accessdate=22 August 2014}} ==Activism== Roche is an active member of the Cleveland branch of the "Confederation of Autonomous American Indian Movement" (AAIM),{{cite web |url=http://blog.cleveland.com/pdextra/1998/07/indian_group_says_man_mand_doe.html |title=Indian group says man does not represent it |work=Cleveland Blog |first=Michael |last=Sangiacomo |date=21 July 1998 |accessdate=6 July 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.aimovement.org/moipr/USvAIMbackground.html |title=BACKGROUND: The United States Government War Against the American Indian Movement |work=AIM Council on Security and Intelligence |first= |last= |date=3 November 1999 |accessdate=6 July 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2014/04/06/facing-man-redface-goes-toe-toe-aim-member-154338 |title=Facing Off: Man in Redface Goes Toe-to-Toe With AIM Member |work=Indian Country Media |first=Simon |last=Moya-Smith |date=6 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}} a separate division of the [[American Indian Movement]]. Robert Roche has been a highly visible figure on the [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]] scene for many decades. Roche would also use his role as a leader in the community to act as a [[character witness]].{{cite web |url=http://www.clevelandmagazine.com/Media/MediaManager/OMalley-defense-memo.pdf |title=In the United States District Court |work=Cleveland Magazine |first= |last= |date=4 April 2014 |accessdate=7 July 2014}} Roche would also provided testimony in the clemency hearing Billy Slagle, who was convicted of Aggravated Murder with death penalty specifications, Aggravated Burglary, Aggravated Robbery in the 1987 murder of Mari Anne Pope, a babysitter who was stabbed 17 times by Slagle with a pair of scissors, while the children she was babysitting watched.{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/08/convicted_murderer_billy_slagl.html |title=Convicted murderer Billy Slagle hangs himself days before scheduled execution |work=Cleveland.com |first=Brandon |last=Blackwell |date=4 August 2013 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} In the appeal, Roche explained that he had contact with the family when Slagle was young when the family came to the American Indian Education Center (Slagle's mother was Native American). Roche recalled alcohol abuse and violence were prominent fixtures in Slagle's home, and believed Slagle would have been incapable of murder if it were not for influence of the alcohol and drugs that he was using, which is why he provided testimony in favor of commuting the death sentence.{{cite web |url=http://www.sconet.state.oh.us/pdf_viewer/pdf_viewer.aspx?pdf=731191.pdf |title=STATE OF OHIO ADULT PAROLE AUTHORITY COLUMBUS, OHIO |work=STATE OF OHIO |first= |last= |date=16 July 2013 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} He currently resides in the city of [[Parma, Ohio|Parma]], a suburb located in the city of [[Cleveland]].{{cite web |url=http://www.news-herald.com/general-news/20140404/fans-brave-weather-for-cleveland-indians-lake-county-captains-home-openers |title=Fans brave weather for Cleveland Indians, Lake County Captains home openers |work=The News-Herald |first=David |last=Glasier |date=4 April 2014 |accessdate=5 July 2014}} He also raised awareness for formerly missing female ''[[Kidnappings of Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus, and Michelle Knight#Amanda Berry|Amanda Berry]]'' after her abduction by writing letters to the city police department and holding candlelight vigils in her memory.{{cite web |url=http://dragonflycanada.ca/amanda-berry-media-coverage-aboriginal-peoples/ |title=Amanda Berry, the Media and Her Mother |work=Dragonfly Services |first= |last= |date=22 May 2013 |accessdate=20 June 2014}} He has also helmed an ongoing battle against the use of [[Chief Wahoo]] as the [[Cleveland Indian]]s baseball team mascot. He has publicly participated in protests against the use of the Chief Wahoo mascot since 1973.{{cite web |url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2012/04/17/standing-and-staying-put-four-decades-protesting-cleveland-indians-chief-wahoo-108481 |title= Standing Up And Staying Put: Four Decades of Protesting the Cleveland Indians’ Chief Wahoo |work=Indian Media |first=Vincent |last=Schilling |date=17 April 2014 |accessdate=5 July 2014}} He also founded the group "People, Not Mascots", a cohort which is dedicated to raise awareness against the use of a race of people as mascots and end the current use of offensive Native American imagery.{{cite web |url=http://msn.foxsports.com/mlb/story/cleveland-indians-fan-comes-face-to-face-with-native-american-awkwardness-ensues-040414 |title=Native Groups Look to Retire the Cleveland Indians' Chief Wahoo |work=NBC News |first=Phil |last=Helsel |date= |accessdate=5 July 2014}} As he explained, "We are not mascots. I'm nobody's mascot. My children are not mascots. "It mocks us as a race of people. It mocks our religion."{{cite web |url=http://msn.foxsports.com/mlb/story/cleveland-indians-fan-comes-face-to-face-with-native-american-awkwardness-ensues-040414 |title=Awkward: Native American comes face to face with Indian caricature |work=Cleveland Frowns |first= |last= |date=4 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}} A protest being held by Roche on 4 April 2014 against the Cleveland's home opening against the [[Minnesota Twins]] at [[Progressive Field]] went viral and gained international attention after a man adorned in Redface regalia, approached Roche.{{cite web |url=http://hardballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/04/04/photo-of-the-day-real-indian-meets-racist-caricature/ |title=Photo of the Day: Real Indian meets racist caricature |work=NBC Sports |first=Craig |last=Calcaterra |date=4 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://deadspin.com/cleveland-indians-fan-in-redface-meets-a-native-america-1558499738 |title=Photo of the Day: Real Indian meets racist caricature |work=NBC Sports |first=Kyle |last=Wagner |date=4 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://deadspin.com/cleveland-indians-fan-in-redface-meets-a-native-america-1558499738 |title=PHOTO: Native American protester meets Indians fan in redface |work=CBS Sports |first=Dayn |last=Perry |date=4 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}}{{cite web |url=https://www.sbnation.com/mlb/2014/4/4/5582656/indians-mascot-chief-wahoo-uncomfortable-chills-up-spine-hard-to-look-at-cant-look-away |title=The most uncomfortable picture in the world, courtesy of Cleveland Indians baseball |work=SBNation |first=Grant |last=Brisbee |date=4 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/04/08/an-editorial-cartoon-on-native-american-mascots-comes-to-life-in-cleveland/ |title=An Editorial Cartoon on Native American Mascots Comes to Life in Cleveland |work=NYTimes |first=Robert |last=Mackey |date=8 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2014/04/cleveland-indians-chief-wahoo-protest |title=Four powerful photos from the protest of Cleveland's Chief Wahoo |work=For The WIN |first=Nick |last=Schwartz |date=5 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}}{{cite web |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/mlb-big-league-stew/cleveland-indians-fan-in-redface-comes-face-to-face-with-native-american-protestor--photo-230345543.html |title=Cleveland Indians fan in redface comes face to face with Native American protestor |work=Yahoo Sports |first=Mike |last=Oz |date=4 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.clevescene.com/cleveland/chief-wahoos-waterloo-a-photo-from-protests-outside-the-indians-home-opener-goes-viral-and-the-debate-over-the-teams-logo-grows/Content?oid=4230259 |title=Chief Wahoo's Waterloo: A Photo from Protests Outside the Indians' Home Opener Goes Viral and the Debate Over the Team's Logo Grows |work=Cleve Scene |first=Sam |last=Allard |date=9 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}} The Cleveland Indian's fan, Pedro Rodriguez, was introduced to Roche by a sports blogger who was working in tandem with filmmaker Brian Spaeth to create a documentary on the use of the Chief Wahoo mascot.{{cite web |url=http://www.clevelandfrowns.com/2014/04/redface-has-another-big-day-at-the-ballpark-in-cleveland/ |title=Redface has another big day at the ballpark in Cleveland |work=Fox Sports |first= |last= |date=4 April 2014 |accessdate=20 June 2014}} On 25 June 2014, major news media outlets began reporting that Robert Roche would file a lawsuit against the [[Cleveland Indians]] organization in July.{{cite web |url=http://cleveland.cbslocal.com/2014/06/25/native-american-group-plans-federal-lawsuit-against-cleveland-indians-logo-team-name/ |title=Native American Group Plans Federal Lawsuit Against Cleveland Indians Logo, Team Name |work=CBS Sports |first= |last= |date=25 June 2014 |accessdate=1 July 2014}} Roche would be suing the team in excess of $9 billion.{{cite web |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2109290-tracking-cleveland-indians-potential-9b-lawsuit-from-native-american-group |title=Tracking Cleveland Indians' Potential $9B Lawsuit from Native American Group |work=CBS Sports |first=Adam |last=Wells |date=25 June 2014 |accessdate=1 July 2014}} According to Roche, compensation would be sought based on the length of time and exploitation which has occurred from the use of the mascot.{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/right-field/381252/are-chief-wahoos-days-numbered-jason-epstein |title=Are Chief Wahoo's Days Numbered? |work=National Review |first=Jane |last=Epstein |date=25 June 2014 |accessdate=1 July 2014}} "We're going to be asking for $9 billion and we're basing it on a hundred years of disparity, racism, exploitation and profiteering," Roche said. "It's been offensive since day one. We are not mascots. My children are not mascots. We are people."{{cite web |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/mlb-big-league-stew/native-american-group-threatens-cleveland-indians-with--9-billion-lawsuit-190106469.html |title=Native American group threatens Cleveland Indians with $9 billion lawsuit |work=Yahoo Sports |first=Mike |last=Oz |date=25 June 2014 |accessdate=1 July 2014}} ==Criticism== Robert Roche has been the subject of criticism from some members within the Cleveland Native American community. [[Philip Yenyo|Philip Joseph Yenyo]], an Aztec Indian,{{cite web |url=http://www.19actionnews.com/story/7220023/bugs-or-no-bugs-indians-fans-ready-for-red-sox |title=Bugs or No Bugs, Indians fans Ready for Red Sox |work=19 Action News |first= |last= |date= |accessdate=11 October 2014}} protester, and member of the [[American Indian Movement]] of [[Ohio]],{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/apr/10/protesters-call-for-indians-to-change-nickname-log/ |title=Indians fans face protest at home opener: ‘We are people, not your mascots’ |work=Washington Times |first=Tom |last=Withers |date=5 April 2015 |accessdate=26 October 2015}} claimed that Roche had constructed a false identity, claiming to have a birth certificate which reveals that Robert Roche was really Jose Roche. However, when asked to validate the nature of the injurious claims, Yenyo was unable to substantiate his accusations with material evidence. Roche has also been accused by members of the Native American community of using the Center as a platform for himself while failing to provide a consistent regimen of services. Roche was also asked by one of the founders of the original [[American Indian Movement]] to stop identifying himself as a member of the organization. According to [[Vernon Bellecourt]], Robert Roche had never been an AIM representative in Ohio. "We have known for some time that he was invoking the name of AIM," Bellcourt said. "We feel if people are doing good work in our name, it's OK. But that is not the case with Roche. We received complaints about him from leaders of the Indian community, and that was enough to cause us to issue the letter." Despite identifying himself as a representative of the Autonomous America Indian Movement, Roche would also state that he was representative or executive director of Cleveland AIM, even doing so in a resume where he describes himself as an "appointed American Indian Movement executive director - Cleveland Ohio, 1994-present." There have also questions raised about the use of grant funds allocated to the American Indian Education Center Roche operates. The Ohio Attorney General's Office launched an investigation into the use of the Center's finances following a 2013 anonymous complaint that alleged the American Indian Education Center mishandled the grant money it had been appropriated, and the fact Roche paid $153,00.00 in salary and benefits to himself that year, according to the tax filing. Closer examination to the available financial records, however, showed that Roche paid himself in relative proportion of grant funding allocated to the organization. In 2012, the American Indian Education Center received $650,000.00 in grant funding, an elevated increase in comparison from previous years. This was due largely to a Department of Education grant aimed at improving education for impoverished and underprivileged kids. In 2011, when the center was allocated $235,000.00 in grant funding, Roche paid himself only $37,000.00. Prior to that year, in 2010, when the Center was allocated $42,000.00 in grants, Roche, who served as the executive director, and the sole full-time employee on staff (who also worked seven days a week), paid himself only $12,000.00. During that same year, he also wrote a $16,000.00 loan for the center. On the tax filing, under "purpose," it read: "Keep Center Open."{{cite web |url=http://npaper-wehaa.com/clevescene/2014/10/01/#?article=2344679 |title=American Indian Movement of Ohio |work=Native Cleveland |first=Sam |last=Allard |date=1 October 2014 |accessdate=11 October 2014}} New details into the mismanagement of money allocated to the American Indian Education Center have slowly emerged. It was revealed that the inspector general for the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services|U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]] also launched an independent investigation into the American Indian Education Center. According to the [[Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration]] (SAMHSA) starting in 2011. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, which is a branch of the U.S. Department of Health, had provided thousands of dollars to the American Indian Education Center from 2011 onwards. However, due to the placement of a "high risk restriction" on the Center, access to the SAMHSA grant money was on a limited basis. The investigation also cites the lack of proper financial management to administer the federal grant. The probe has also identified certain irregularities into the expenditure of funds provided by the SAMHSA. These irregularities included the $136,000.00 salary Roche paid himself in 2012, which did not appear to be concordant with wages supplied in grant documentation provided by the American Indian Education Center, the flat fees paid to the center's grant writer, McGuire & Associates, are inconsistent with standard practice, and the Center's bylaws giving Roche governing authority and control over his board of directors, are not in keeping with federal guidelines, which state that the board should operate independently of its director. There are also matters of personnel costs, related taxes and fringe benefit payments that The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration is looking into.{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/naymik/index.ssf/2015/01/anti-chief_wahoo_activist_robe.html |title=Anti-Chief Wahoo activist Robert Roche faces federal scrutiny: Mark Naymik |work=Cleveland.com News |first=Mark |last=Naymik |date=8 January 2015 |accessdate=9 January 2015}} One grant received by the American Indian Education Center received in 2012 carried over into 2013. However, the rant was terminated by the grantor, the Ohio Department of Education, which decided that the program being funded by the grant was ineffective. Roche also made an attempt to open a second education center for American Indian people in the city of [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]], [[Ohio]] in spite of financial difficulties faced during 2012. Although he cited poor health and financial difficulties, Roche registered a 1989 [[Jaguar Cars|Jaguar]] in the "unfinished" Columbus Center's name in December 2012. According to Roche, he donated the car to the center, where he plans to raffle the vehicle in the name of American Indian services. ==See also== *[[American Indian Movement]] *[[Chief Wahoo]] *[[Native American mascot controversy]] *[[Sundance (activist)|Sundance]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.netzkraft.net/mitglied.php?teilnehmer=1488&lang=englisch American Indian Education Center] *[http://clevelandaim.us/ Cleveland American Indian Movement] {{Native American mascot controversy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Roche, Robert}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:People from Cleveland]] [[Category:Apache people]] [[Category:Chiricahua]] [[Category:20th-century Native Americans]] [[Category:American Indian Movement]] [[Category:American civil rights activists]] [[Category:Native American people from Ohio]] [[Category:Native American leaders]] [[Category:Native American activists]] [[Category:Activists from Ohio]]

'''Sayerr Jobe''' was the founder of [[Serekunda]], the largest city in [[The Gambia]].<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/201503030708.html Gambia: 'Sayerr Jobe's Name Cannot Be Easily Forgotten'- Says a Descendant]</ref> Sayerr, originally from the Sine-Saloum region of Senegal, migrated to the Gambia in the mid 19th Century and is believed to have initially settled around Jinack Island in Banjul, before relocating to the southern bank of the country where he established Serrekunda<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.gm/books?id=hF9ADwAAQBAJ&pg=PA103&lpg=PA103&dq=sayerr+jobe&source=bl&ots=2yoz3J7mvj&sig=neZVw28vvx-EGCFDAn-WLVjyux8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjq_4Xk_43eAhXJKFAKHUKYC-o4ChDoATAHegQIAxAB#v=onepage&q=sayerr%20jobe&f=false|title=The Gambia|last=Briggs|first=Philip|last2=Fenton|first2=Simon|date=2017-11-21|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|isbn=9781784770648|language=en}}</ref>. He died in 1896 and is buried at the Serrekunda Cemetery<ref name=":0" />.

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:theresa le pore.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Theresa LePore]] --> '''Theresa LePore''' is a former [[Supervisor of Elections]] for [[Palm Beach County]], [[Florida]]. She is most notable as the person who designed the infamous "[[butterfly ballot]]", used in the [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000 presidential election]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://cnn.com/2001/ALLPOLITICS/stories/01/05/palm.beach.ballot |title=Ballot nightmare lingers for Palm Beach elections chief |first=Gary |last=Tuchman |date=2001-01-05 | publisher=Cable News Network }}</ref> This would lead the [[Mass media|press]] to nickname her "Madame Butterfly". Following the [[2000 United States presidential election recount in Florida|controversial results of the 2000 election]], she lost her re-election bid in September 2004 and left office in January 2005.
In [[Jay Roach]]'s ''[[Recount (film)|Recount]]'', LePore is played by [[Jayne Atkinson]].
==Career== LePore grew up in Palm Beach County, attending [[Cardinal Newman High School (West Palm Beach, Florida)|Cardinal Newman High School]] in West Palm Beach, Palm Beach State College in Lake Worth and Florida Atlantic University in Boca Raton.
She started her career in the Supervisor of Elections Office in 1971 as a file clerk. She quickly rose through the ranks and achieved the position of Chief Deputy Supervisor in the late 1970s. During the 1980s she also moonlighted as a ramp clerk at [[Palm Beach International Airport]].
In 1996 LePore changed her political party registration to Democratic after deciding to run for the position of Supervisor of Elections.<ref>[http://www.commondreams.org/headlines04/0901-01.htm LePore Loses Re-Election Bid] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080919073940/http://www.commondreams.org/headlines04/0901-01.htm |date=2008-09-19 }} from [[CommonDreams.org]]</ref><<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1996-10-15/news/9610140096_1_motor-voter-law-palm-beach-county-show-proof |title=Elect Democrat Theresa Lepore As New Supervisor Of Elections |publisher=Articles.sun-sentinel.com |date=1996-10-15 |accessdate=2018-03-30}}</ref> She was elected as the Palm Beach County Supervisor of Elections in November, 1996 and re-elected without opposition in November, 2000. In 2004 she lost re-election as Election Supervisor. Prior to the election she had changed her political party designation to independent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mvRPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QQkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6486,478951|title=Ocala Star-Banner - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref> After leaving the Supervisor of Elections Office in January, 2005, she was employed by the Palm Beach County State Attorney's Office for a short period, enabling her to receive her full pension from Palm Beach County.
She then worked at her alma mater, Cardinal Newman High School in West Palm Beach, Florida as director of development.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/06/AR2006100600937.html |title=Victim Advocates, Fla. Diocese Urge Foley to Name Alleged Abuser |publisher=Washingtonpost.com |date=2006-10-07 |accessdate=2018-03-30}}</ref> until January 2009.
LePore is (or was) a member of the following organizations: * [[American Society of Public Administration]] * The Election Center * [[Kiwanis]] of Flagler Sunrise * [[League of Women Voters]] * International Association of Clerks, Recorders, Election Officials and Treasurers * Women's [[Chamber of Commerce]] of the [[Palm Beach County, Florida|Palm Beaches]] * Florida State Association of Supervisors of Election. Theresa served terms as Secretary, Vice-President, and President of FSASE. * Executive Women of the Palm Beaches * The Hispanic Chamber of Commerce of PBC * Hispanic Human Resources Council * Girl Scouts of Southeast Florida
She is writing a book about the 2000 election and the butterfly ballot she designed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/localnews/content/local_news/epaper/2008/08/15/0815lepore.html|title=Ex-elections chief LePore writing book about 2000 presidential election|publisher=|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref>
==Election controversies== [[File:Butterfly Voters View.jpg|thumb|"Butterfly ballot" from Palm Beach County, 2000 election]]In 2000, to accommodate the large number of presidential candidates eligible in Florida, LePore designed a staggered two-page format with candidate names on alternating sides of a central punch button column. Conservatives falsely commented that the same ballot was successfully used in the 1996 election; in fact, it had never been used in a Palm Beach County election among rival candidates for office.<ref name="crow">{{cite book|title ="Oh, Waiter! One Order of Crow!"|first=Jeff|last=Greenfield |year=2001|publisher =G. P. Putnam's Sons| location=New York |pages=215–216}}</ref> In 2000, the confusing design led to an increased amount of miscast votes in the presidential election (votes that would otherwise have been a decisive reversal) and consequently achieved notoriety. A study by ''[[The Palm Beach Post]]'' speculated that voters confused by Palm Beach County's butterfly ballot cost Al Gore the presidency.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://archives.cnn.com/2001/ALLPOLITICS/03/11/palmbeach.recount/ |title=Newspaper: Butterfly ballot cost Gore White House |date=2001-03-11| work=CNN}}</ref>

{{Infobox short story | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = To Mars and Providence | author = [[Don Webb (writer)|Don Webb]] | country = United States | language = English | genre = [[Science fiction]]/[[Horror fiction|horror]] [[short story]] | publication_type = [[Book]] | published_in = ''[[War of the Worlds: Global Dispatches]]'' | publisher = [[Bantam Spectra]] | media_type = Print ([[Anthology]]) | pub_date = June 1996 }} "'''To Mars and Providence'''"<ref>The title is possibly in reference of ''[[To Arkham and the Stars]]''.</ref> is a short story by American writer [[Don Webb (writer)|Don Webb]], published in ''[[War of the Worlds: Global Dispatches]]''. It is a conflation of ''[[The War of the Worlds]]'', the [[Cthulhu Mythos]], and the biography of [[H. P. Lovecraft]].
==Plot summary== The story begins on August 12, 1898, twenty-nine days after the death of eight-year-old Howard Philip Lovecraft's father. Howard observes a [[Martian (War of the Worlds)|Martian]] cylinder crash into [[Federal Hill, Providence, Rhode Island|Federal Hill]], an event that he had been predicting in his dreams for three years.<ref>Dreams and their predictive nature were a common theme in Lovecraft's writing; this is also similar to the dreams of [[The Call of Cthulhu#Henry Anthony Wilcox|Wilcox]] in ''[[The Call of Cthulhu]]''.</ref> Being a "gentleman of pure [[Yankee]] stock [of] the true chalk-white [[Nordic race|Nordic]] type"<ref>See [[H. P. Lovecraft#Racism|Lovecraft's views on race]].</ref> Howard decides to investigate the landing, and witnesses the opening of the cylinder and emergence of the Martian occupants. When the Martians fire upon onlookers with their [[Heat-Ray|heat ray]]s, he faints.
Howard reawakens three days later in his home. His mother, blissfully ignorant of the danger in staying behind in Martian-occupied [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]],<ref>In observing this, Howard notes that "it was perhaps a blessing that the human mind is unable to correlate its contents," reflecting the famous opening line of ''[[The Call of Cthulhu]]''.</ref> informs him that he was taken into the Martian cylinder, before being rescued by a [[Brown University]] librarian named [[The Dunwich Horror#Henry Armitage|Armitage]].<ref>Brown was the basis for Lovecraft's [[Miskatonic University]].</ref> Howard observes the spread of the [[red weed]] and the movement of [[Tripod (The War of the Worlds)|fighting machines]] and feels an intense longing to explore the crash site, but realizes that his mother will not let him. He resorts to drugging her with a [[sedative]] in her [[malted milk]], before heading out into the city.
Howard arrives at St. John's Church, where he witnesses a tripod placing an artifact into the steeple and to which he feels the strong pull. Climbing to its top, he finds a glowing [[trapezohedron]]<ref>A reference to ''[[The Haunter of the Dark]]''.</ref> accompanied by a strange sound of distant flutes.<ref>In Lovecraft's work, the sound of flutes is associated with [[Nyarlathotep]].</ref> Picking up the object, Lovecraft is surrounded by a shifting, sentient [[Colour out of space (species)|unearthly colour]]. It asks if he is "one of us," stating that prior to the invasion, a number of Martian minds were telepathically sent to occupy human bodies to report, with some failing to return.<ref name="GR">These are references to the practices of the [[Great Race of Yith]] from ''[[The Shadow Out of Time]]''.</ref> It begins to relate the story of the "Martians" history to Howard.
The species originated in another [[solar system]], emigrating to this one ages ago. They established two colonies, one on [[Mars]] that thrived and one in [[Leng (plateau)|an area]] of [[Antarctica]] that was destroyed due to [[climate change]]. The survivors on Mars engaged in [[selective breeding]] programs that created an advanced, immortal physical form.<ref name="ET">These are references to the [[Elder Thing]]s from ''[[At the Mountains of Madness]]''.</ref> As a side effect, some Martians developed the capability to engage in [[astral projection]], and made contact with the other two races of the system: Humans on Earth, and a "[[Mi-go|fungoid race]]" on a [[Yuggoth|distant planet]].<ref name="GR" />
The Martians engaged in trade with the fungoid race, entering a golden age and building "labyrinthine Cyclopean structures" before entering a decline marked with a population shrinkage and increasingly decadent artwork.<ref name="ET" /> However, this collapse ends with a discovery beneath [[Syrtis Major Planum|Syrtis Major]]: an [[R'lyeh|underground series of impenetrable vaults]] that the fungoid beings explained as being the home of the [[Great Old Ones|elder godlike beings]] that were Mars's first masters, and would return from their undead dreaming when the stars were aligned.<ref>This is a reference to [[Cthulhu]] and his [[star-spawn]].</ref>
This discovery sent the normally cool and calculating Martians into a frenzy of terror, and they destroyed as many of the elder gods' idols as they could find, before finally deciding to leave Mars for Earth, where the elder gods have no interest. It was for this reason that the Martians sent out their psychic spies - of which Howard apparently was one. By this time, the colour out of space begins to fade, and Howard finds himself on Mars, in a vast hall filled with "mathematically-perfect music".<ref>This could refer to the speech of the [[Elder Thing]]s and their [[shoggoth]] imitators from ''[[At the Mountains of Madness]]'', or to the eponymous ''[[The Music of Erich Zann|Music of Erich Zann]]''.</ref> Howard enters the hall, and as he does, the Martian inhabitants begin to exit in fear; Howard realized the cause when he looks up and sees that one of the feared elder gods is standing within the hall. Howard approaches it - and realizes that he is standing before a mirror.<ref>This is a reference to the [[ending twist]] of ''[[The Outsider (short story)|The Outsider]]''.</ref>
The narration states that the shock of this sent Howard back to Earth, with no memories of the event, and in later years he became one of the skeptics who claimed there had never been a Martian invasion of the Earth.
==Other notes== *Howard described the Martians as [[wikt:eldritch|eldritch]] in appearance, and uses descriptions similar to the appearance of [[Cthulhu]] and the [[Elder Thing]]s. *The narrative notes Howard's early rejection of [[Santa Claus]] and embrace of [[atheism]]. *Howard's mother refers to him as [[Abdul Alhazred]]. *Howard mentions cylinders landing in [[London]], [[Paris]], [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], and [[Texas]] (referring to other stories from ''Global Dispatches'') and also mentions the irony of Martians landing in [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]]'s [[Italian people|Italian]] section when it was [[Giovanni Schiaparelli]] who discovered the [[Martian canal]]s. *Howard mentions that one of the very few things in the world that seemed true to him were "certain tales in ''[[One Thousand and One Nights|The Arabian Nights]]''", echoing statements of Lovecraftian characters concerning the ''[[Necronomicon]]''. *The back cover of ''Global Dispatches'' depicts three Martian tripods excavating something amid icebound glaciers; this is presumably them seeking the remains of their lost Antarctic colony.

{{Use British English|date=September 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox scientist | name = William F. Barrett | image = William f barrett.jpg | birth_date = {{Birth date|1844|2|10|df=yes}} | birth_place = Jamaica | death_date = {{Death date and age|1925|5|26|1844|2|10|df=yes}} | death_place = }} '''Sir William Fletcher Barrett''' (10 February 1844 in [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]], Jamaica – 26 May 1925) was an English [[physicist]] and [[Parapsychology|parapsychologist]].<ref name="royalsoced.org.uk">http://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf</ref><ref>McCorristine, Shane. (2011). ''William Fletcher Barrett, Spiritualism and Psychical Research in Edwardian Dublin Estudios Irlandeses'' 6: 39-53.</ref>
==Life==
He was born in Jamaica where his father, [[William Garland Barrett]], who was an amateur naturalist, [[Congregational church|Congregationalist]] minister and a member of the [[London Missionary Society]], ran a station for saving African slaves. There he lived with his mother, Martha Barrett, née Fletcher, and a brother and sister. The family returned to their native England in Royston, Hertfordshire in 1848 where another sister, the social reformer [[Rosa Mary Barrett]] was born. In 1855 they moved to Manchester and Barrett was then educated at Old Trafford Grammar School.<ref name="ONDB">[[Alan Gauld|Gauld, Alan]]. (2004). ''Barrett, Sir William Fletcher (1844–1925)''. Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/71319, accessed 2 Feb 2011].</ref>
Barrett then took chemistry and physics at the [[Royal College of Chemistry]] and then became the science master at the [[London International College]] (1867–9) before becoming assistant to John Tyndall at the [[Royal Institution]] (1863–1866).<ref name="ONDB"/> He then taught at the Royal School of Naval Architecture.<ref name="ONDB"/>
In 1873 he became Professor of Experimental Physics at the [[Royal College of Science for Ireland]]. From the early 1880s he lived with his mother, sister, and two live-in servants in a residence at Kingstown (now [[Dún Laoghaire]]). Barrett discovered Stalloy (see [[Permalloy]]), a silicon-iron alloy used in electrical engineering and also did a lot of work on [[sensitive flame]]s and their uses in acoustic demonstrations.<ref name="ONDB"/> During his studies of metals and their properties, Barrett worked with W. Brown and R. A. Hadfield. He also discovered the shortening of nickel through magnetisation in 1882.<ref name="ONDB"/>
When Barrett developed [[cataract]]s in his later years, he also began to study biology with a series of experiments designed to locate and successfully analyze causative agents within the eyes. The result of these experiments was a machine called the [[entoptiscope]].<ref name="ONDB"/> He was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society]] in June 1899<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www2.royalsociety.org/DServe/dserve.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqCmd=Show.tcl&dsqDb=Persons&dsqPos=1&dsqSearch=%28Surname%3D%27barrett%27%29| title = Library and Archive Catalog|publisher= Royal Society|accessdate = 10 December 2010}}</ref> and was also a fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]] and the [[Royal Dublin Society]]. He was knighted in 1912. He married [[Florence Barrett|Florence Willey]] in 1916.<ref name="ONDB"/> He died at home, 31 Devonshire Place in [[London]].<ref name="royalsoced.org.uk"/>
Barrett's last book, ''Christian Science: An Examination of the Religion of Health'' was completed and published after his death in 1926 by his sister Rosa M. Barrett.
==Psychical research==
[[File:William Barrett Spiritualist.png|thumb|Barrett]]
Barrett became interested in the [[paranormal]] in the 1860s after having an experience with [[mesmerism]]. Barrett believed that he had been witness to thought transference and by the 1870s he was investigating [[poltergeist]]s.<ref name="ONDB"/> In September 1876 Barrett published a paper outlining the result of these investigations and by 1881 he had published preliminary accounts of his additional experiments with thought transference in the journal ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]''.<ref name="ONDB"/> The publication caused controversy and in the wake of this Barrett decided to found a society of like-minded individuals to help further his research. Barrett held conference between 5–6 January 1882 in London. In February the [[Society for Psychical Research]] (SPR) was formed.<ref name="Oppenheim 1985">[[Janet Oppenheim|Oppenheim, Janet]]. (1985). ''The Other World: Spiritualism and Psychical Research in England, 1850-1914''. Cambridge University Press. pp. 137-372. {{ISBN|0-521-26505-3}}</ref>
Barrett was a [[Christian]] and [[Spiritualism|spiritualist]] member of the SPR.<ref name="Oppenheim 1985"/> Although he had founded the society, Barrett was only truly active for a year, and in 1884 founded the [[American Society for Psychical Research]].<ref name="ONDB"/> He became president of the society in 1904 and continued to submit articles to their journal.<ref name="ONDB"/> From 1908–14 Barrett was active in the Dublin Section of the Society for Psychical Research, a group which attracted many important members including Sir John Pentland Mahaffy, T.W. Rolleston, Sir Archibald Geikie, and Lady Augusta Gregory.<ref>McCorristine, Shane. (2011). ''William Fletcher Barrett, Spiritualism, and Psychical Research in Edwardian Dublin''. Estudios Irlandeses. Journal of Irish Studies 6: 39-53.</ref>
In the late 19th century the [[Creery Sisters]] (Mary, Alice, Maud, Kathleen, and Emily) were tested by Barrett and other members of the SPR who believed them to have genuine psychic ability, however, the sisters later confessed to fraud by describing their method of signal codes that they had utilized.<ref>[[Ray Hyman|Hyman, Ray]]. (1989). ''The Elusive Quarry: A Scientific Appraisal of Psychical Research''. Prometheus Books. pp. 99-106. {{ISBN|0-87975-504-0}}</ref> Barrett and the other members of the SPR such as [[Edmund Gurney]] and [[Frederic W. H. Myers]] had been easily duped.<ref>Wiley, Barry H. (2012). ''The Thought Reader Craze: Victorian Science at the Enchanted Boundary''. McFarland. pp. 82-94. {{ISBN|978-0786464708}}</ref>
As a believer in [[telepathy]], Barrett denounced the [[muscle reading]] of [[Stuart Cumberland]] and other magicians as "pseudo" thought readers.<ref>Nicola Bown, Carolyn Burdett, Pamela Thurschwell. (2004). ''The Victorian Supernatural''. Cambridge University Press. pp. 87-108. {{ISBN|0-521-81015-9}}</ref>
Barrett helped to publish [[Frederick Bligh Bond]]'s book ''Gate of Remembrance'' (1918) which was based on alleged psychical excavations at [[Glastonbury Abbey]]. Barrett endorsed the claims of the book and testified to Bond's sincerity.<ref>Asprem, Egil. (2014). ''The Problem of Disenchantment: Scientific Naturalism and Esoteric Discourse, 1900-1939''. Brill Academic Publishers. p. 330. {{ISBN|978-9004251922}}</ref> However, professional archaeologists and [[Skepticism|skeptics]] have found Bond's claims dubious.<ref>[[Joe Nickell|Nickell, Joe]]. (2007). ''Adventures in Paranormal Investigation''. University Press of Kentucky. pp. 48-49. {{ISBN|978-0-8131-2467-4}}</ref><ref>[[Kenneth Feder|Feder, Kenneth]]. ''Archaeology and the Paranormal''. In [[Gordon Stein]]. (1996). ''The Encyclopedia of the Paranormal''. Prometheus Books. pp. 32-43. {{ISBN|1-57392-021-5}}</ref>
In 1919, Barrett wrote the introduction to medium [[Hester Dowden]]'s book ''Voices from the Void''.
==Dowsing==
Barrett held a special interest in [[Dowsing|divining rods]] and in 1897 and 1900 he published two articles on the subject in [[Society for Psychical Research|Proceedings of the SPR]].<ref name="ONDB"/> He co-authored the book ''The Divining-Rod'' (1926), with [[Theodore Besterman]].<ref name="Mill 1927">[[Hugh Robert Mill|Mill, Hugh Robert]]. (1927). ''Behind the Divining Rod''. ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' 119: 310-311.</ref>
Barrett rejected any physical theory for [[dowsing]] such as radiation.<ref name="Mill 1927"/> He concluded that the [[Ideomotor phenomenon|ideomotor response]] was responsible for the movement of the rod but in some cases the dowser's unconscious could pick up information by [[clairvoyance]].<ref>[[Martin Gardner|Gardner, Martin]]. (2012 reprint edition). Originally published in 1957. ''[[Fads and Fallacies in the Name of Science]]''. Dover Publications. pp. 102-103. {{ISBN|0-486-20394-8}} "The first significant "scientific" study of the subject was made in 1891 by Sir William F. Barrett, professor of physics at the Royal College of Science, Ireland. ''The Dowsing Rod'', by Barrett and Theodore Besterman, published in 1926, is one of the leading references on the subject. The book's thesis is that the turning of the rod is due to unconscious muscular action on the part of the dowser, who possesses a clairvoyant ability to sense the presence of water."</ref><ref>[[Gordon Stein|Stein, Gordon]]. (1996). ''The Encyclopedia of the Paranormal''. Prometheus Books. p. 231. {{ISBN|1-57392-021-5}} "Barrett, who believed in telepathy, acknowledged that the dowser's unconscious moving of the rod could be the result of autosuggestion stimulated by cues from the environment. He felt that in some cases, however, the diviner's unconscious was picking up information about the underground water through clairvoyance."</ref>
==Reception==
Barrett has drawn criticism from researchers and skeptics as being overly credulous for endorsing spiritualist mediums and not detecting trickery that occurred in the [[séance]] room. For example, author [[Ronald Pearsall]] wrote that Barrett was duped into believing spiritualism by mediumship trickery.<ref>[[Ronald Pearsall|Pearsall, Ronald]]. (1972). ''The Table-Rappers''. Book Club Associates. p. 219</ref>
Skeptic [[Edward Clodd]] criticized Barrett as being an incompetent researcher to detect fraud and claimed his spiritualist beliefs were based on [[magical thinking]] and primitive superstition.<ref>[[Edward Clodd|Clodd, Edward]]. (1917). [https://archive.org/stream/questionifmandie00cloduoft#page/265/mode/2up ''The Question: A Brief History and Examination of Modern Spiritualism]''. Grant Richards, London. pp. 265-301</ref> Another skeptic [[Joseph McCabe]] wrote that Barrett "talks nonsense of which he ought to be ashamed" as he had poor understanding of [[Magic (illusion)|conjuring]] tricks and failed to detect the fraud of the medium [[Kathleen Goligher]].<ref>[[Joseph McCabe|McCabe, Joseph]]. (1920). [https://archive.org/stream/isspiritualismba00mccarich#page/59/mode/2up ''Is Spiritualism Based On Fraud? The Evidence Given By Sir A. C. Doyle and Others Drastically Examined'']. London: Watts & Co. pp. 59-60</ref>
Psychical researcher Helen de G. Verrall gave Barrett's book ''Psychical Research'' a positive review describing it as a "clear, careful account of some of main achievements of psychical research by one who has himself taken part in these achievements and speaks to a large extent from personal knowledge and observation."<ref>Verrall, Helen de G. (1913). ''Psychical Research by W. F. Barrett''. International Journal of Ethics. Volume 23, No 2. pp. 239-240.</ref> However, in the ''[[BMJ|British Medical Journal]]'' the book was criticized for ignoring critical work on the subject and being "a negative assault on scientific method generally".<ref>Anonymous (1912). ''A Study Of Psychical Research''. ''[[BMJ|British Medical Journal]]''. Vol. 1, No. 2667. pp. 308-309.</ref>
